review_title: A good company for growth but you need to take the initiative.
pros: IP has a lot of good opportunities, it has been a place I have recommended to friends to work and several have done well and others have become stagnant and left. What I would recommend for anyone who wants to advance in this company is to be direct in what you want to do long term with your manager. Most people who struggle are waiting to be told what to do versus trying to build their careers and finding people to champion them. If you don't like networking and building bridges, IP's culture focus on relationships will be burdensome.
cons: New employees are onboarded and integrated into the company poorly. This has improved slightly in the last 2 years but many senior leaders are fixed into their mindset of you don't know anything till you have been at the company for 10+ years.

review_title: Pay is Acceptable, Company Culture Needs Massive Improvement
pros: Management tried to do a good job at accommodating employees in terms of needing time off for important duties, and the pay is great if you have the qualifications and even more if you have an advanced degree.
cons: Company culture is very traditional and it is as if the company refuses to navigate/conform with the current environment. It is very early 1900s. It is easy to feel like a number and a robot rather than a team member. The company cares deeply about you getting your results (which is perfectly fine) but struggles to find balance between not treating its employees like a number. I have been at the company for several years and haven't had a single conversation with upper-management, whereas at previous companies, upper-management made it a priority to at least know the names of the employees doing all of the core work. Room for upper mobility is extremely limited and it is almost as if the positions are already pre-reserved for others.

review_title: Not the Worst You Can Do
pros:
-The pay is the most significant advantage. IP does pay a living wage and there are yearly raises.
-The benefits are OK. About 3 weeks vacation plus most holidays, expensive but decent health insurance, good 401k matching.
-Not the worse way to get your food in the door for other technology positions
cons:
-International Paper's bulk of employees are very old, and so a lot of the processes, policies, and services are extremely outdated.

-You will find it VERY hard to thrive if you are not a social butterfly, a networking whiz, a previous intern, or if you don't know the right people. This is a pervasive issue company-wide but it's particularly bad in the IT department and in the Service Desk, where those liked by management will get promoted regardless of qualifications, performance, or process. I have seen people getting fired just to give the position to someone's family member. I have seen entire procedures get changed to give promotions to unqualified candidates who happen to be best friends with management. I have seen entire positions get created for no purpose other than hiring specific individuals.
-The environment within the Service Desk has eroded through the years. You will be micromanaged to extremes, you will not have many opportunities to grow or learn beyond the scope of the job, and you will see your rights and privileges diminish as months go by.

review_title: Fairer than most companies their size. Most ethical in their class.
pros:
Lots of upward mobility for the talented and politically savvy. Overall an ethical company. Salaried professionals tend to be well-paid - most other industries and especially smaller companies cannot compete with the compensation. If you are a conscientious type (look that up in the Big 5 personality traits), then you'll love and do well at this company and you'll be rewarded with promotions every 2-3 years. Conscientious types tend to be less creative and more industrious in their work habits. 

This company also takes safety very seriously at the corporate and mill-leadership levels.
cons:
As with any large corporation, there is entirely too much red tape. This comes with having 50K+ employees so this isn't a personal strike against IP as company but its just a common characteristic found in companies of this magnitude. The company has international agendas that it panders to, namely with the UN, WEF, etc. so that may or may not be a problem for some. In many settings, there is pressure to conform and a fear of speaking up and telling the truth the way you see it, especially if it goes against the prevailing narrative.

Lastly, more about the creativity piece - This company is very mature commodities-based company and therefore has less need for someone to re-invent the wheel for them. Creativity is difficult to express in such rigid, mature industrial processes such as making paper for the largest paper company in the world. If having a creative role is your cup of tea, consider looking for a company that is still young in their business life cycle and who has a demand for innovation on a much shorter time frame. Those industries will be more appreciative of creative types (openness to experience). Again, go look up what a creative person is like in the Big 5 personality traits and go listen to Jordan Peterson on the subject of corporations and openness vs. conscientiousness. That will give you a better idea of what you're up against with this industry. If you are a creative type and you choose to work at IP, my recommendation is to have a creative hobby on the side that you take very seriously so that you can satisfy your innate desire to create something new. It is my belief that the company will fail to offer adequate opportunities to be creative - this ties back in to the company being too big for its own good and has too much red tape - such size and red tape limits how much creativity the company can entertain and the margins are too low and the stakes are too high for them to be taking large risks with paradigm-shifting ideas. 

Consider yourself adequately warned!

pros: Pay is great, and some hourly employees are great folks.
cons: Management sucks. Particularly the management. I worked 8 days in a row 12 he says. I was averaging 55 hrs a week not because I asked for it but because they were short handed. I had a dental surgery on a day I was not scheduled to work. My boss called and asked if I could work on that night( my surgery in the morning). I said I could and started getting ready however I was told that you should always get a lot of sleep before surgery. Now with that in mind I was suppose to get off at 7 am and had surgery at 8:30am. So I called my boss and told him he said well work untill 3 am I never said yes. I worked 3 days after that and was supposed to be off for 3 days. But they fired an employee so he asked me to work I said yes. Friday a supervisor seen I was vomiting and wanted to send me home. I text my boss told him that a supervisor was sending me home because I was vomiting but I didn't want to go because I was scared it would be held against me. I never heard back so I went home. Saturday I was sick and Sunday on the way to work about 15 min before shift start my boss finally text me back( after I had called and text all day seeing I were suppose to work) telling me no not tonight. The next day I was called and fired for the dentist thing. This was a week after that had happened and I had worked days before that.

review_title: Great Feeder Company for the rest of the Industry
pros:
Very Safety conscious company. Possibly too many safety rules. 

They have a fantastic program for recruiting and training new engineers out of College. (REACH)

Lots of training and advancement opportunities if you are motivated in your first few years. Very equal treatment at some mills for men and women.

They have a great 401k match and company contribution for retirement.

If you are an engineer they will give you lots of opportunities for growth even outside of your area of study if you are interested.
cons:
After you are established in your career, it's not terribly different than other companies so you see a lot of people jumping ship between 3-10 years.
 
They do not do cost of living adjustments in the mill system to compensate for differences between the middle of Alabama and the West Coast but they do this in the Box Plant system. It make no sense!

The insurance is very expensive and Cigna coverage is not very good. Most people were on spouse's insurance if that was an option. For 2 people I was paying over $700/month! No option for employee+1. 

Still a male dominated industry and not much being done to allow women to succeed long term in the field.

Eventually the arbitrary requirements they have rolled out throughout the company will hinder them from competing with their competitors.

pros: Decent pay & vacation time

pros: -The pay...kind of. Not really. Compared to other paper companies, they pay is mediocre at best. So no pros, honestly.
cons:
-Mediocre/expensive benefits that you pay for BEFORE you get them.
-Hilariously Inept Management...they create problems where there don’t need to be any, refuse to perform maintenance until the machines break, encourage employees to snitch/backstab, and blame production employees for anything and everything that goes wrong.
-Extraordinarily hostile environment. Again, everything is your fault. Even if there isn’t any work to be done, you will be told you are not working fast/hard enough. Expect to be harassed almost constantly.
-monotonous, unfulfilling work. The most boring, repetitive job I have ever had.
-HR will not help you. With anything.
-Weak Union. Expect little to no help if you have issues with management.
-Horrible schedules.
-General incompetence on the part of management. Somehow, in the middle of a paper bag shortage, they couldn’t figure out how to make the plant break even, let alone turn a profit. It takes effort to fail that hard. Naturally, this was the fault of the production employees.

job_title: Assistant Machine Operator in Louisville, KY
pros: Decent hourly base pay, and it's a union.
cons:
High stress environment, one or 2 good managers but most play the favoritism game. Overtime is ridiculous, when people on other shifts call in, you can be forced to work overtime on their position, last minute notification. Countless times I was notified 5 mins before my shift ended, that i was forced to stay over another 4 hrs because someone else called in. If you say you cant stay, you get pointed for it. Why should i take responsibility for other employees call ins? It's not my company to run. You guys figure it out.
Absolutely no work life balance, you practically live there, especially if you're maintenance.

review_title: Comparatively the best in-class work environment and compensation
pros:
This review ONLY applies to the fiber-side of procurement (both in Virgin and Recovered Fiber sectors of the industry):

-Excellent compensation (in the fiber procurement sector) EXCLUDING health insurance 
-They make reasonable accommodations (i.e. work from home) 
-Highly professional culture - low occurrence of low-class/ inappropriate behavior
cons:
-Is overly politicized and fairly easy to commit career suicide - sometimes without even realizing you did! You need to have tact & be familiar with the skills associated with the "dog & pony show". A silver tongue w/ a can-do and positive attitude are required for most people to advance to certain levels in the company. Just being good at your job is not in itself enough to soar with this company - you have to develop your soft skills although there have been a few old-school hold-outs that made it pretty far up in the ranks prior to the progressive HR agenda being implemented. Just like ANY OTHER BIG CORPORATION, there are unspoken social rules that are unethical & hypocritical (double-standard) that one must play by in order to advance IN CERTAIN AREAS of the company. Not all areas require these unspoken soft skills to advance consistently. 
-Health Insurance benefits are scant while premiums are high (this may not be a criticism of the company benefits as much as it is a criticism of the current health insurance and medical regulatory environment. Packages are largely unchanged from when I started back in 2012 - but what did change was the premiums doubled between 2012 - 2018 for family while the coverage remained stagnant. Obamacare is to blame for the premiums while IP is to blame for not adapting and remaining competitive by carrying the weight of the premiums - further premium hikes now get passed to the employee. 
-Match pay on 401K is marginal - average is around $.60 on the dollar for the first 8% (it isn't terrible but I've seen considerably better)

review_title: Good for the short term our breaking into the industry.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Federal Way, WA
pros:
Pay is livable.
Wonderful co-workers that you will become attached to like family and won't want to leave, even when the environment becomes toxic.
Flex start time, based on work.
Free coffee.
Student loan assistance.
cons:
Business direction is shaky. The division I was in had more turnover (corporate, management and onsite positions) this past year than I have seen in 5 years of working for this company. Corporate is constantly moving their employees around between businesses or location sites. Each corporate leader is looking to implement different standards and goals, so sites keep having to change business direction. Recently there were two projects that were bringing in revenue (and had potential to bring in much more if marketing developed better customer leads) that were ended. During tough fiscal times that the industry is going through, one must wonder why these projects were ended. 

Direct leadership are over worked because they often have their own project work to do, typically manage other people and their careers, as well as continually having to take on new duties since this location is in a hiring freeze but has had several retirements and turnover. They will toe the corporate line and not go to bat for you if it means rocking the boat.

Communication is awful at pretty much every level. Between project managers, scientists and technicians. Between management and everyone else. There is too ambiguity and inconsistency. This in the end can be expensive because if work is done incorrectly, you have wasted hours and materials. Much information has to pass through the rumor mill instead of formal communication to all employees. Creates mistrust and misunderstandings, has been compounded by CoVid-19 while 50-66% of the building are working from home.

Few opportunities for for tangible growth (raises and promotions are far and few between, even for valuable employees/high performers). It is often that you are presented with "growth and leadership" opportunities, however, this is their way of adding responsibilities to your job that expand your capabilities but will not be financially compensated for. Sure, you will get the annual raise, but to move through PLs takes promotions. In 5 years, I have only seen 4 promotions. All except one of which were for people that had been there 7-13 years and had been waiting 5-7 of them for a promotion. Bonus program is only available to those at high scientist and management level. 

There are more than a few examples where technicians are doing scientist work yet have not been formally promoted. Those onsite are relied up now more than ever to take care of things that are not their responsibility. CoVid-19 has allowed for many of the scientist and project managers to "work from home" and some have become disconnected from the onsite work. For example, there are certain scientist that expect next day or two turn around for their work, just because they decided to finally submit something (because they are coming up against a deadline and realized they need some data to present) when there is work already in process to be completed. 

Clique culture. Most of these employees have worked together for 10+ years and are able to regale you with stories of the "good old days". Though most are friendly, I have seen cases of when people just don't fit in and can lead to being black balled out of working in an area or a project. Beware the bullies and steamrollers! If you're into that, manipulation of the "right" people will work here. You will find that if you target and befriend highly influential people, it will put you in a position to be treated favorably. Some managers will not evaluate you by your work ethic but instead how you the façade that is presented. 

Instead of productivity and quality in which one completes their work, there is a heavy emphasis on networking and attending all of the non-essential meetings and activities. There is no possible way to do your job successfully and attend everything. People who are in attendance of everything are those who want to 1. avoid their actual work responsibilities, 2. brown nose to the "right" people to be noticed. 

Company values (like safety) tend towards being just lip service with no action, particularly if the price tag to upkeep their values is too expensive. The only safety officer onsite had their position eliminated. The nurse that was contracted onsite 3 days a week, no longer is available, instead there is a virtual nurse. Despite having 3 medical incidents onsite within the past year. AND weathering a pandemic. Also, due to the decreased capacity of the building, they are waiting to re-sign their evening custodial service. We have just one (amazing, kind and hard working) custodian during the work hours that covers cleaning and disinfecting the high touch areas AND daily cleaning. Keep in mind that the square footage of the building did not change.

review_title: Salary side is full of liars eho smile to your face then stab you in the back.
pros: Good pay for employees hired before 2013. New hires mske substantially less and it's NOT worth it.
cons:
Worst working hours in the country. You work 7 days on 3rd shift then off for one day, 7 days on 2nd then off for one day, 7 days on first then off for 4 days. You work nights, weekends, holidays. IP refuses to pay bonus holiday pay.
Company preaches safety constantly, but it's all a sham. If there's an accident, the employees are blamed for getting hurt. All of the Safety Observation Cards, where numerous employees reported a safety issue to Management will disappear and the person who got hurt will be thrown under the bus. Management regularly ducks responsibility for inaction, complacency, and outright lies. 
IP hires bargain price college kids for Management positions who dont know the first thing about the jobs and have no idea how to work or talk with men who've been pouring blood, sweat, and tears into tough jobs since the kids were playing in a sandbox.
They hire felons for the tax break, and allow them to be lazy, yet reprimand hard-working employees if they use harsh language. God forbid some lazy idiot gets their feelings hurt after theyve been asked to do simple tasks multiple times in a polite way.
They bleed money through antiquated software, policies and safety procedures. They refuse to entertain fantastic ideas by employees unless they company can screw the employees overbon yet another contract issues.
IP will cut out their eyes to spite their face. 
This was a fantastic place to work and raise a family before IP bought it. The entire company is a cancer now.

pros: Competitive pay and willingness to help employees grow.  If you are willing to live in locations in the middle of nowhere and able to move from one location to another than there is a lot of opportunity to grow. REACH program was great for entry level employees to learn about the paper making process, how to conduct yourself in meetings, IP's Project Development Process, and various tools that can go on that resume like SAP.
cons: I worked at one facility for 4 years and transferred to another thinking I was advancing my career with a new experience. The facility I transferred to was the Franklin VA Mill which had previously been closed. I worked there for a year on several projects to change the facility to a Mill that makes Fluff. I had the worst boss ever. He was to busy to assign me projects so sent me out to hunt for my own. When any project did run into trouble he offered no assistance nor advise. I was treated like a REACH Engineer even though I came in knowing all the tools and demonstrating all the ability to successfully execute projects. I was given no credit for the numerous projects I had completed successfully but given all the credit when a small issue arose, which I fixed as well. I had weekly sit downs with my manager to go over my projects and he still could not tell you what I had done right.

review_title: Company with many strengths, but limited by the politic and work systems
pros:
Opportunities are plentiful for the candidate that is willing to relocate and amenable to playing the political game.  In an ideal world, the pay has great upside potential.  

The company, as a whole, is well positioned to continue to be a leader in the global paper products industry.
cons:
Politics and management style impact your career, income, and job satisfaction.  Two employees with nearly identical skill sets, working for two different managers in two different geographies will have two completely different opportunities.  In one region, management promotes, recognizes, and rewards good performance.  In the second region, the management makes decisions which limit the employees success, but blames the employee for poor performance. The management in region two is less likely to recognize good performance. 

Having a manager that is willing to share the credit for good performance and recognizes good performance to mid-level and top level managers, is the difference between an employee that will be promoted, and an employee that will become stagnant and unproductive.

pros: Good salary and the people that work with you are friendly.

December we let IT staff go and then turn around and create Strategic Analyst position for someone with no qualifications and they do not post it. If you are not on the managed move list to get promoted and no one can tell you how to get on the list. Senior leaders routinely are deceptive about their motivation especially in Information Technology. Ethics is something they preach but do not practice. I have had directors and senior managers information technology lie to my face and when you show them your CSA is impacted. If you are long term employee your contribution does not count. Want a prime example, CORE have a budget, they often spend time with VP, Directors, Sr. Managers, etc. They are spoon fed positions. They get training on leadership that long term employees do not get. CORE have little experience and even if you are not accepted into because you do not meet requirements by CORE, a VP or Director can have you put into CORE. Just go look at some of the CORE GPAs.

pros: Great corporate culture and focus on safety
cons: Slow process of making decisions

pros: Job security, pension 401k medical dental,
cons: Sometimes too many hours. Hot in summer

job_title: General Labor in Kansas City, MO
pros: There is not an upside. This place is awful.
cons: The temperature inside the plant is 10 or 20 degrees hotter than outside at all times. Management treats union very poorly. Verbal abuse comes with the territory.

job_title: Paper Machine Helper in Three Rivers, MI
pros: Pay was great. Benefits were better than most places.
cons: Lots of hours. Management was decent. Fast turnover rate.

pros: Good Pay, Lots of work, Benefits, 401k Plan, Reliable
cons: Weekend work, Bad management, Long hours, Hard to progress

job_title: SAP ABAP Developer in Memphis, TN
pros: Lots of opportunities for growth and career development
cons: Large corporation - stuck in their ways

review_title: All the overtime you want, and some you don't
pros: Some of the best pay in the area, all the overtime you want you basically can write your own paycheck, if you are a good worker your fellow co workers will look out for you. When everything is running smoothly can be the easiest job in the world. SOME of management will work with you as best they can.
cons: Most of management has absolutely no clue what goes on inside the actual plant or don't care, and the few that do are hard pressed to help you because they have to kiss up to the higher ups to stay in good graces. 12 hour shifts can be long especially during upset conditions. Heavy industrial environment can be dangerous if you get careless. At my facility we are underpaid/compensated when compared to equivalent jobs at other mills. Insurance is meh. Can be called in if given enough prior notice. Shifts can change week to week ( especially for new employees) making it hard to make long term plans outside of work.

pros: I really enjoyed the job, the pay was good and I learned a lot. My immediate manager was great to work for.
cons:
They made a really hasty decision to shut down an entire mill that has always been profitable (was still profitable at the time of shut down) to send business to an over seas mill. They made a cost cutting goal for us to help the company (mind you we were still profitable)  and we doubled the cost cutting savings and everything was looking good. We were all proud of ourselves with posters plastered throughout the mill letting everyone know we exceeded our goals, then one day one of the hireups came and shut us down.

 something like this can happen at any time. As long as the International paper mill you are employed arent in the crosshairs, the job is great. but you dont have to be in bad shape to be shut down.

pros: IP is a fair & ethical company that offers a consistent and steady career advancement for those who are willing to stand out from the rest. IP has many global opportunities for those who are seasoned and offer global talent to the company. Decent benefits and opportunities to grow in both strengths and weaknesses.
cons: Iconic atmosphere of secularism, bureaucracy and political correctness. This type of culture is typically created by such large companies in effort to avoid lawsuits and hurt feelings amongst employees of different backgrounds. However, in the end it only stiffles authenticity and candidness, causing many people to feel out of place or resent the entire system as a whole since it rewards uniformity rather than originality or creativeness.

review_title: Great company. Don't start you career at corporate.
pros: IP has sent me to all parts of the US. I have worked on several different projects that allowed me to take ownership and receive credit for the work that I accomplished. IP has been understanding and supportive when I needed them to be. The pay seems to be on par with other careers. Upper management is accessible and as friendly as I would expect an executive to be. I am very satisfied working for IP.
cons: Relocation is a necessity if you want to move up in the company. You could just stay at corporate, but, unless you have prior experience in the field, you are only going to move up so far before you level out.

job_title: E and I Technician in Riverdale, AL
pros: Excellent pay for the location
cons: Work life balance and antiquated shift

pros:
The company is very large, lots of mobility, well established, training was very good. Good compensation package. Employees are well compensated too. 

Mentoring program was there but mentors need to be trained. 

They stressed safety....this was very high point for me personally. They never did anything unsafe.
cons:
There was to many layers of managers. When something needed to be reviewed it took two layers of managers above you to get it done. 

When issues would be brought to the attention of managers it was never addressed it would always be a finger pointing game. It should have been lets work together  get this problem fixed.  Liked to play the blame game

You could not review or rate upper management. Unprofessional upper managers.

Upper management did not care why supervisor turnover was so high. It appeared that they were not interested 

High supervisor turnover..within a year 1/3 of my colleagues changed. 

While in meetings not treated with respect.   Talked down to.  Threats of termination is were often while in group meeting.

pros:
- Employee lunches (free food occasionally)
- Company matches up to 5% towards your 401k
- Life is good if you are in management/supervisor position. You get to watch the grunts make the company millions.
- Management/Supervisors receive "company cards" and get to treat themselves and each other to breakfast, lunch, dinner, drinks, golf outtings, you name it. Must be nice.
cons:
- You are over worked and under paid.
- Supervisors/Management will receive annual bonuses in the thousands because you the worker worked harder, faster, and did not get hurt while doing so.
- Oh you busted your butt to get the work done sooner than expected? Here take this brush and go scrup the floor until its time to clock out.
- Verbal abuse
- Constantly being micromanaged
- You will receive a write up for EVERYTHING.
- If you enjoy working twice as hard as those above you and receiving half the pay, this is the place for you!
- Looking to move up? Good luck. 
- This company would rather hire someone who has never done the job to come be your boss rather than promote veteran employees.

pros: They have good benefits and every quarter, they have a production meeting. Offer good food, and raffles for some pretty good prizes. People get recognition.
cons:
Ah, where to start... They have the pay scale posted in the break room. They have new hire pay, 6 months, 12 months and 18 months. After Working by myself on second shift, I have a great review. I asked my supervisor if I would be getting a raise and was told, "I don't see why not". After waiting a few weeks, I was told "no, they want to see more." I asked what I need to do to receive a raise, again it was "more". They could not give me any detail. I asked what area I need to improve and again I was told that they want to see more. They did not say that anything was wrong, they just wanted to see if I would keep up with what I had been doing. Same thing happened on my 12 month review. When I asked why I wouldn't make more than starting pay for being there for 12 months, I was told that there were people there for 10 years still making starting pay! I asked them why they had the raises put on a calendar system and I was told that they had to put something down!
I left them with only a 2 day notice.
Do you self a favor and don't work there.

pros: I cant think of a single one. The pay isnt even that great now that you can go anywhere and make fifteen bucks an hour .. so .. they watch you pee now? Who doesnt like that?! And you get to pee twice because that's "always" been the policy and just noone knew .. right ..
cons:
I could go on all day .. not exaggerating. They're two faced, liars, back stabbers, thieves (better check your paychecks friends! More than likely theyve either taken money or extra psl hours .. or both). I honestly cant name a single good thing about the place. 
Even the few good supervisors there dont stand up for what's right when the rest of management are harassing and bullying someone so I just dont have any respect for then either. 
Still not exaggerating either. If one person decides they dont like you, you can be superman, the absolute best at ever job there that theyve ever seen, and it doesnt mean a damn thing. They (supervisors and higher management) will harass you and they will encourage the other supervisors to do the same. Theyll even go as far as lying about everything under the sun to get you or get people to help them get at you. Its sick.

pros: I work at the Carrollton,Texas Container plant. There are no pros about working for this location of IP. The management is complacent and the entire production process needs an overhaul, especially with the delaminated and warped paper that our customers complain about.
cons: This IP plant overlooks experienced employees and puts friends, family members and unqualified persons at top positions who lack experience and leadership skills. A current employee who only has three years experience was made leadman and more qualified and more experienced employees of over 15 years experience were ignored. These decisions bring lack motivation,resentment and production and our customers suffer for these bad decisions.

pros: Pay is very competitive and the job is very interesting if you like to be hands on. Many locations give any endless chance for advancement. Employee safety is the primary focus.
cons: Most local promotions are done from the outside. Advancement almost always requires a move to a different location. Also Management changes every 2-3 yrs and the rules change with them.

review_title: Decent company but very old fashioned
pros: Good ability to move around internally, especially as a new hire.  Fairly good pay, especially for Memphis.
cons:
Very old fashioned. I guess one shouldn't expect forward thinking from an old manufacturing company, but i t was very frustrating how behind the times IP was in many ways. Horrible maternity leave, the idea of paternity leave literally would generate a lol from management, they wouldn't even consider temporary flexible work arrangements.  IP is one of the last companies to still have a pension (closed for new hires).  This pension means the company skews VERY old as people will not leave.  The company is wildly out of touch with  under 40 crowd, much less the priorities of recent college grads.   In many ways its like 1985 at IP.   Almost every senior person you will interact with is a married old  white man. 

Cant speak for all groups, but communication was horrible in mine.  No one ever had any idea what the hell was going on.

review_title: Depending what shift are you starting you’ll be OK
pros: You can make a lot of money with them if you don’t mind giving up your life.They have a point system they use so if you have a emergency they tell you to use your points and if you run out of points you are a goner
cons: For the most part I was ok till they moved me with out asking me to a 3rd shift on the corrugater were I found the disrespectful people I have ever met when I asked for the disrespect to stop it turned violent when I reported it to HR with witnesses I only ended up getting myself fired they did not want to hear anything Me or my witness had to say

review_title: Big Pay difference between Union location & non-union
job_title: Machine Operator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good benefits, although a little high on health insurance.  worked at both locations in San Antonio Tx & there is an unbelieveable difference in pay between the Union shop & the non-union location. Plus Union location gets a company paid retirement in addition to their 401-k!  Can't complain about that!  A lot of the workers make more than supervisors or Mgrs because of all the overtime worked. Good people make it a great place to work. Hands down SA Central location is better cuz of pay, benefits, people, etc.
cons: You should put in a change of address, because you're gonna spend most of your time there because of overtime! I worked at both locations & supervisors at both can be jerks.  Theres no loyalty on the companies part.  Long term employees leave  cause there offered better jobs, not as many hours

review_title: Not for the faint of heart...and prepare for chaos
pros:
Compensation is high and benefits are great.
Coworkers at your level are great and willing to help out when you need it.
Seems like a great company if you are single or willing to not see your family for what seem like days.
cons:
Compensation is low when you consistently work 60+ hour weeks including the weekend. Was not informed of this when interviewing.

Work life balance? Nope, most workers are senior in age and will lack empathy for younger workers. Turnover is high due to this, which leads to "No change" in group thinking.

Coworkers above you give little to no respect to those below as they think of their career first.

A lot of talk and no walk on culture change. IP is facing 30-50% retirement in 10 years but hasn't changed on the workplace culture.

1 year commitment for salaried hires, you will count the days until you can leave if you get a bad mill.

pros:
Moderately good pay for the position
Friendly coworkers
cons:
The way they do shift changes is awful. If you’ve been requesting a different shift for months, and some guy who has a week or month of seniority over you and just requests it the day before, he’s gonna get it, not you, because he has a bit more seniority over you.

Paying for union and using their benefits is mandatory

Attendance “point” system is awful for the first 90 days of probation. If you’re throwing up or even coughing up blood and need to call out for a few days, better start looking for a new job.

A lot of “don’t ask? Won’t tell” mentality. You’re almost expected to ask all different kinds of questions because no one will tell you if you don’t ask.

If you’re the new guy, you are literally the runt of your shift. If no one wants to do overtime, either you’ll have to do it or you’ll get a mark on your attendance.

pros: Seems to be stable company. Its a very big company. Pay meets the market.
cons:
You do as your told. Micro managed to death. There seems to be a lot of back stabbing. no one trust anybody. Nobody really seems to care or be invested in the operation. We just show up and do as we are told. Good or bad. if a problem or something bad happens the managers all go into a blame game.   
All the new managers seem like they don't want to be there or they just don't care. Our site is punishment duty for them it seems. Before you do anything you better have someone else set up that you can blame it it goes wrong. Your manager has you set up for their failures

review_title: Not a difficult job, great benefits, great starting pay.
pros: A great place to get your foot in the door and rise to better opportunities in the future. The pay is high, work is simple, union takes good care of its people. Best of all, there is a sense of trust that you get from your superiors; very comfortable atmosphere.
cons: Some mishandling of scheduling and logistics by management which causes rifts with hourly workers. Accountability is not always pointed to the appropriate party. Worst of all, the negativity by a majority of employees; at least half of the production workers are stuck in the past and refuse to think optimistically or progressively, creating a sour vibe that I would suggest new hires try to avoid. Make of it what you want, not what others tell you to.

pros: They have a really competitive pay especially if you are in Memphis where the cost of living is so low. Raises every year. Managers who want to see you grow with the company. Memphis is a great city for new grads and the campus is a nice place to work.
cons: Very old school. Not much vacation early on and you really have to earn your seat at the table. I think this is causing young talent to run fast. But if you sit and wait your turn it can pay off.

pros: International Paper has a strong rotation system for new hires out of college where they can move to different positions after 12-18 month rotations.  It is a very secure job to have in Memphis. IP offers the standard package of Corporate Benefits. There are many places to move if you so desire to test/expand your skills in other fields.
cons: The environment doesn't lend itself to having all employees feeling important. Though continuously ranked on Computer Worlds Best Places to Work in IT.  Leadership at IP tends to take an 'if it ain't broke don't fix it' stance to innovation and development. As a result the IT environment is dull. Company bonuses are only given to upper management so non-management employees have NO incentive to actually care about the company, its profits, or its stance in the industry. IP has no culture and only senior management is excited about the company (see above)

review_title: Average company, but can be difficult to develop your career
job_title: Applications Development Specialist II in Memphis, TN
pros: Competitive salary offer for entry level employees - Memphis is a city with a low cost of living, and the pay for IT positions is very good for entry level employees.  IP is one of the largest companies in Memphis allowing employees to take advantage of local discounts and promotions such as Grizzlies and Redbirds events.
cons:
Industry heavily influenced by economic trends
Highly focused on cost savings above all else

The company gives full control of your 'releaseable' status to your department manager.  This can effectively block any career development if you are filling a business need during a extended hiring freeze.  The company is currently engaging in 'cost savings through attrition'; many positions are not being back filled and duties are spread over existing employees.  In efforts to save money, tuition reimbursement, hardware refreshes, and BlackBerry service have all be discontinued indefinitely.

review_title: Good Company But:  No Accountability for Middle Managements Professionalism  eg: GM's
pros: Good pay &  benefits. Opportunities to advance. Corporate personnel great to work with.
cons: Remote plant's GM's have no sales experience are then expected to manage sales teams. I believe this to be a very weak area for the corporation. Also, non performing sales representatives are not held accountable for their time or lack of production. In my case may sales colleague continually cold called in my territory with communication, GM approved causing conflict. Lack of professionalism.

pros: A large company with many opportunities both in the US and around the world.  IP pays well, with benefits on par with the competition.  You can potentially move between functions in addition to transferring from one locale to another.  The atmosphere is, for the most part, informal and most managers are more than willing to share information and knowledge for the good of the organization.
cons: Many of the managers are unschooled in how to manage people; many are swayed by appearances rather than results in their promotion and treatment of subordinates.  Politics play a major role in advancement beyond middle management ranks.  It is often assumed that performance is directly related to hours spent at the office.

review_title: A company that strives to continually improve the manufactured products as well as the service they provide.
pros: The salary and benefit packages are competitive within their respective markets. As a leader in the pulp and paper market there are many operations throughout the US therefore affording opportunities for growth and advancement. Diversity within the company's senior leadership team all the way down to the production floor provides a culture that reflects the communities and customers they service.
cons: Information doesn't flow as smoothly as it should. Communication can be slow to filter down to those who carry out the orders. Changes in processes or procedures are not presented effectively at times. Often those responsible for implementing these changes arent sufficiently informed/trained on the new process and therefore unable to effectively train the employees who are affected by the change.

review_title: You do not need to know stats to do the job.
pros: Market Leader, strives for pest practices.  The company is environmentally focused and does care about employee well being and safety.  Each employee is required to take 4 safety credits during the year.  Topics range from plant safety to office safety to child car seat safety to home security.  They do care about your well being.
cons: Corporate policy can really suck at times.  If you are one a project that spans multiple divisions and one of those divisions is being sold off, you have to reapply for your job even if your time spent on that division was very minor.  Outsiders with no box plant or mill supply chain experience will have a tough time convencing older IP workers that they know something about supply chain.

pros: It seems to be a stable company
cons: I applied for a position and a month later received a call for an interview, after the interview I recived a call for 2nd interview and was told a decision would be made within 2-3 weeks ,I was told I was one of the 3 candidates for the final selection and I would be updated. I made an inquiry after a month becasue I had another interview lined up and was told that a decision still had not been made but that I would be notified one way or the other. I never got a call back to tell me one thing or the other. Out of courtesy to me taking the time to interview during odd hours of the day ,I should have been notified.

review_title: Successful company committed to safety, people development, and doing business with integrity.
job_title: IT Business Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros: Internal movement is encouraged and championed. The company has strong leadership and people development processes.  It is the market leader in most markets segments it competes in.  Good 401k plan.  Has proven success in declining markets and above market growth in growing markets.  Stock price has increased in the last 5 years.  Values clear expectations.  Easy-going about sick days and personal appointments during work hours.  International opportunities.
cons: Slow vacation growth.  Underperforming and non-core businesses seem always at risk of being sold.  Facilities are located in remote locations which can discourage internal movement.

pros:
Pay
Co-workers are awesome
Supervisors are top notch
cons:
Management above the supervisors  are terrible

Promotion process is a joke. They use the employee handbook “policies” when it fits their narrative for the month.

If you become complacent in a 12 hour shift and make a mistake you will be written up.

review_title: I have been very successful in this company.  I love my job and I am concerned why other individuals do not like theirs.
pros: International Paper allows all employees to receive medical benefits.  The company provides great health insurance that covers the whole family.  Promotions are guarenteed if you have been employeed long enough.  This company will not let anyone stay in a position for years.
cons: The only cons are having to work solo on projects and having to work with foreigners that have different methods of doing businesses.  That goes with international business though.  Learning to adapt and be willing to do things differently can be hard at times.

pros: You get your paycheck and if that's all you want then it's the company for you. If you can talk a good game chances are upper management will do no leg work to prove you can do what you say.
cons: Horrible management practices, doesn't value long term employees or their families. This company says safety is #1 but we all know it's about the money. They put safety practices in place that make it near in possible for you to perform then hold you accountable for it. Arm chair safety policies in place by people who can,t haven't, and won't ever understand what it takes to get a job done. It would be like having your child write an ergonomics program for someone who does desk work.

review_title: They treat workers fairly, but will do work.
pros:
-Mostly good treatment for workers (3 weeks vacation starting, good sick leave policy, good new parent leave policies)
-Good health insurance
-Small student loan repayment help
-Challenging projects
-You probably won’t get bored
-Strong emphasis on worker safety
cons:
-Older technology
-Lack of flex work options (WFH to be used sparingly)
-Can be very easy to be encouraged to do far more than 45 hours of work per week—can sometimes be 60-70 for weeks at a time 
-Culture leaves something to be desired—IP has a very old corporate culture. Very risk averse, mostly closed disruptive ideas despite innovation initiatives 
-Very behind the curve on technology

review_title: Opportunities exist but make sure you are in charge of your career planning from day one.
pros: A large company with opportunities to grow if you are willing to move often.  Salaries are good but you must know your value to the organization and be firm when it's time to negotiate your compensation.   IP has a great attitude pertaining to training and can be very supportive when an employee's training needs are identified.
cons: Large company that makes it difficult to figure out your place and the value of your potential within the organization.  Like most large companies, corporate politics can play a significant role in your career.  At times it seems like how you are perceived is as important as how you perform.  This "perception issue" can make or break your career.

review_title: A Great Company in A Shrinking Market
job_title: Program Manager, Color and Appearance in Loveland, OH
pros:
International Paper is the largest paper company in the world; therefore they frequently lead and others follow them. They are not afraid of innovation. For example, I was tasked in 2005 with raising the brightness of commodity paper from 84 to 92 and CIE whiteness from 100 to 146. 

There is often room to grow in this company with its many paper mills and roles to support them.

P.S. I worked at IP until October 31, 2009.
cons: As a very large company, there is a lot of bureaucracy to weed ones way through. Sometimes it seems that reports are required just for the sake of having the reports themselves. They did not frequently seem to drive the business objectives of the company.

pros: Great place to work if you're willing to work hard you will have a great career there and moving up is easy as long as you put in the effort and care about you're work.
cons: They brought in new management at fox valley aurora and they were a disaster until the day I was let go, worked my but off for 5 years and left with nothing I felt.  Showed up 10 mins late to work my first time ever showing up late to work and machine was down and I was let go.. I had one point for missing a punch even thought I know I punched in.. My dad was in a car accident and I left 2 hours early on a Saturday and got a point.. Moral of what  all I'm saying it has great perks and great environment to work for, but you're managers and supervisors do not have you're back when times are tough.

job_title: Packaging Line Operator in Sumter, SC
pros: The best thing I like about working at IP is enjoying the Benefits of salaried employees.  Leadership is great and the company as a whole is one of most safety minded engaged facility that I have ever worked for.  IP Sumter Sheeting that is!  Not one complaint in the area of safety.
cons: 12 hr rotating shifts, while not all that bad tends effect your sleep habits.  I think we could stand another dollar or two, I think we are the lowest paid IP facility that exist.  That in-turn is good for company cost and expense's, but not for the employee or the moral withing a facility where everyone does they're best to see the company succeed.

review_title: Stable company but firmly entrenched in older mentalities and practices, too conservitive.
pros: They will do the best they can to retain their cooperate staff in these difficult economic times; as long as you have pulled your share. The paper industry is not going any where anytime soon and International Paper is very involved in conservation and sustainable practices. Company is very active in international expansion.
cons: Very conservative cooperate environment and overly traditional. The one progressive change they made was too drastic and incorrect; selling all of the land. They also terminated the pension program recently. Project management regularly incorrectly estimates, and is too accommodating to schedule slippage and budget overflows. Outsourcing is becoming a common practice.

pros: Outstanding Benefits, especially pay, dental, and vision. Health benefits are around normal. Outstanding support if you go out on sick leave. Really are a safety first culture that genuinely cares for their employees physical well being.
cons:
Expect long hours as a salary maintenance person. In fact, you will basically give a blank check for your time. It would be difficult to, say, plan a diner night out during the week, in advance. This is mainly due to the current poor condition of mill equipment. In fairness to IP, they are making considerable capital improvements to address the issue, however they aren't there yet.
Management culture can be on the hostile side, especially around unplanned equipment breakdown events.

review_title: Great company that has potential to be a great work environment
pros: Executive Leadership has a great vision and great values. Company has the potential to be a really fantastic work environment if they manage their talent pool effectively.
cons: Values and policies don't filter down to middle management (transparency, communication, and basic corporate policies). Need to start really looking at the impact of management. Middle management would benefit from more training in effectively managing and engaging their teams. Some managers are hired through networking but are not effective leaders.

pros:
*Great opportunities for advancement, not just at your own mill, but at other locations within the company. 
*IP does a great job training their engineers and management in problem solving techniques, leadership classes, technical training from experts, etc. 
*Pay is great. One of the highest paying employers in the locations I have been in. 
*I loves the transparency within the company. As a new engineer, I had several opportunities to interact with senior Vice Presidents and the CEO.
cons:
*Work/life balance is not good. Expected to work long hours with no comp time. 
*New engineers are expected to work as a shift manager within their first few years. Many are not interested in this, but it's pretty much forced in order to advance.

review_title: If you love a cubicle, this is the job for you
pros:
Pay and flexibility were good. Many of my coworkers could bring their kids to work. 
Covered parking with security and an onsite cafe and Starbucks
Remote access to work from home
cons:
Conflicting metrics across the company never let you feel like you do a good job
Poor training
Lots of turnover of millennials, company still using old practices, not very efficient. Alot of double work keeps you trapped at your desk or in endless meetings that fail to generate change withing the business group.

pros:
Decent pay (competitive)
Great benefits (besides health insurance)
Great people to work with
Advancement opportunities
Extra activities provided by company
Large company with opportunity to relocate
Fast paced environment
Very busy all the time and the time flies by
cons:
Very top down approach, everything has to go through your manager, which then goes to their manager etc. It is a lenghty process to get anything approved. I do not know if it is a power struggle or what. 
Everyone gets the same raise every year as long as you do your job.
Since it is such a large company sometimes you do not get the recognition you deserve. 
Hard to have a work life balance since it is such a stressful and demanding job.

pros: Environment, Safety Culture, Benefits, Salary, Training. I can't say enough about how  much I love working at IP. I have a flexible schedule and the ability to do my job without being micromanaged. Pay is right on the mark for the industry and the benefits can't be beat. 1 week vacation for the first year, then 3 weeks vacation after that. Floating holidays + awesome health insurance. IP is a class act and I feel very lucky to be a part of the team!
cons: They push you outside of your comfort zone to improve. Sometime the sales goals are pretty aggressive, but as long as you're giving it your all, you'll be fine!

review_title: The good and bad of working at IP
pros: The pay and benifits for working with IP is a definite positive.  With the exception of shiftworkers, flexibility of hours to fit your home life are is also a positive.  International Paper does well at family and community relations.  They go out of their way to do the right thing when it come taking care of employees and employee families.
cons: Most managers at IP do not seem to relate to hourly workers.  Communications from salaried to hourly workers, and hourly to salaried workers is poor at best.  Like most U.S. based companies, Inernational Paper is downsizing regularly.  The impact on employees and community are always going to be a "downside".

review_title: A good company in a tough business environment.
pros: The company offers competitive pay and benefits with strong emphasis on a safe work environment. There are many facility locations, leading to the possibility to live in an area where one wishes. Many employees have enjoyed a long stable work history with the company. The company has a diverse workforce with clear anti-discrimination policies.
cons: The company is undergoing downsizing of salaried positions. This appears likely to continue. Virtually all decisions are made from the top. There are strict bureaucratic procedures for all activities. Most facilities are located in remote areas resulting in long commutes for those who don't wish to live in the country. Unofficially, promotion requires relocation to facilities around the country/world.

review_title: IP is a good company, but is struggling right now as so many are.
pros: There is fairly open communication from management about the company's direction. Employees are given feedback regularly about their performance. The company tries more than most to make employees feel appreciated.
cons: The challenges presented by a dwindling stock price lead to unpopular management decisions. At times these decisions can seem heartless. One example would be the decision to close a profitable plant when changing the focus of the company. Instead of selling the plant to a competitor, the plant was closed and the hard-working employees who had been making profits for the company were left without jobs.

review_title: Above average pay with a good benifits package. For the industry it's a good place to work.
pros: Benefits are above average and a wide variety of health plans are offered. Long Term Disability, Life Insurance and a good matching 401K is offered.
cons: Just another warehousing logistics job. Managers are sub par along with mist of the labor field. Everyone seems to carry a chip on their soldiers and not thankful for what they have. At 20 bucks and hour for driving a truck and 18 for working in a warehouse the workers need to perform much better. Moving up in IP can be difficult unless you have a job which allows you to converse with many people.

review_title: I'm a maintenance mechanic, been here 14 years and I still love this job!
pros: Great money!, hourly, overtime and profit sharing. NEVER hassled about time off EVER! Lots of additional trade training. My opinion and experience counts. They have an excellent safety program and they take safety very seriously. Everyone is equal, you can talk to anyone from supervisors and area managers all the way up to the mill manager anytime about anything. I like the atmosphere, it's laid back when things are going good and serious and challenging when they aren't.
cons: Typical stuff like lack of communication, why don't they fix this or that, nothing to lose sleep over. I can't think of anything that would make me want to seek another job.

pros: Great benefits, especially the 401k matching and healthcare options.  Excellent career path development.  Good coworkers who genuinely care about each other and doing a good job.  Compensation is very competitive. Strong commitment to the environment and sustainability.  The opportunity to follow your career path to other locations (some even international!).
cons: The union leadership in the manufacturing facilities can be challenging to work with at times, however some of the union guys have been the best guys to work with in terms of knowledge and commitment.

review_title: Good Company with a great work environment
pros: Management is fair with workload. Pay is good for first job in the field.  Have a great network linking  you with other new hires, interns and as many people as possible.  Overall great environment to work in.
cons: First couple steps up the ladder seem more about putting your time in than actively excelling.  Some people tend to work less hours frequently and not receive any punishment. Teams tend to not immediately include you so you occasionally have to find your own work

review_title: I've loved working here, but know some folks who have had a bad expierece.
pros: Travel opportunities.  Many locations all over the US and abroad to work at.  Job Security even in a rough economy for most places.   Good pay for salaried folks, not sure about hourly?  Wide variety of jobs, from manufacturing to sales to sitting in a cube
cons:
Too many bosses, to few workers in mos cases.  If you get attached to a speciic location, there is alwasy a chance it could get shutdown.  Have to try and maintain some ties with the corporate office.
Sometimes the stupidest people dont get fired, they just get moved around to another departments.

review_title: Good for robots, Not so much if you want a future.
job_title: Operator's Assistant in White Bear Lake, Optional[MN]
pros: Good if you need a job, and don't mind management making it up as they go along, at your expense.
cons:
Where to start? I guess we will start at the top and work our way down. The plant general manager, walks around calling employees "peter buffers" the things that come out of his mouth are repulsive and offensive. How he has not been sued yet is beyond me. 

The atmosphere consists of bend over at the drop of a hat. we will sacrifice every last one of you to move product and protect are bonus.

job_title: Machine Operator in Carol Stream, IL
pros: Very easy job. If you like to keep busy and make some good money and overtime. This is your place.  Learned a lot from this place. Good people. Hardworking.
cons:
Overtime is mandatory. So if you bail out on a day that requires you to come in early or on a Saturday, it will effect your attendance. Meaning you will be let go just for that. No matter what excuse.  
Hours are long and this job will wear you out pretty good.  You will be busy and your free time will be limited. So if you have kids. Plan carefully. 12 hour shifts are very common with this place.

review_title: Some Mills Much Better Than Others
pros: Tex mill has a good market for the products it makes.  Occasional market driven downtime but good solid future.
cons: The Tex mill was built on the cheap and suffers from it.  You can make butter with a toothpick, but its damn hard.  Review system dictates lots of low performers even when you look at what they do and are impressed at what they do.  So messed up.  Raises are good for younger engineers, not so much for more experienced.

pros: Great people, good pay, opportunity for development if willing to relocate; all the benefits of working for a major corporation
cons: Senior Management is isolated from the day to day; need to listen to the employees more, program for promoting people is not always effective; highly competitive across business segments; stressful with long hours/weeks

pros: I cannot think of anything good, pay and benefits suck for what you give up no work life balance, work atmosphere is next level hell
cons: seven days a week 8 to 12 hours per day mandatory, not knowing if you will have to come in early or stay late to cover someone shift, all equipment run down broke or rigged to run, no PM in years, completely a reactive approach to maintenance, have to call in sick on a Sundays for kids and grand kids birthdays,  point system, management sucks, two faced coworkers, lie to you about what needs finished or do not report downed equipment or calls so they can leave go home, no tools - tools ordered are put on hold and they expect you to work on the broken equipment with worn out tools,

pros: Great benefits, really rewards their employees financially
cons: Work life balance is terrible. Management is completely out of touch with reality. The culture is just that... very cultish. There is nothing down to earth regarding the people who make decisions in the facility. To the ones who are delusional regarding their abilities/policies, just be confident in your delusion and you will go very far. Speaking the truth and being honest in this facility is extremely discouraged in the most passive aggressive manner possible. If you are an expert in corporate double-speak, then this is the place for you.

review_title: Your experience is very dependent on your manager
pros:
I enjoyed my first position with IP, good pay and low stress and a great boss. However I had issues when I moved out of Memphis for a new position. I had a difficult position but I believe it would have been easier and less stressful if I had support from my manager. I ended up leaving because I felt the 
"ok" salary wasn't worth the stress and disrespect from my manager.
cons: Allows poor performers, bullies, and non-cooperative people stay in the company. Company loyalty wins out over performance.

review_title: Learned a lot in art department.
pros: Understanding manager, great art and customer service team, Tuition reimbursement, 401k, 15 days pto, a few sick days, no weekends, paid over time,  wellness program that helps save a LOT on health insurance, and the pay is good.
cons: For me with an hour drive and young kids work/ life balance is NOT GOOD. Last minute orders needed the next day are a constant and communication between the smaller  art department and the larger sister art department is an area of tension and in need of much improvement. An additional member of the smaller team making it 6 instead of 5 would help greatly. Easy fix that I'm sure will be applied in the future.

review_title: Great Place to work in Memphis
pros: Well known and respected employer in Memphis. Great culture overall.  Professional and friendly environment. Great leadership and career development program. Varies team to team, but in supply chain you have a lot of flexibility and work/ life balance. In general, most employees are quite happy and motivated. Standard benefits, no bonuses in supply chain.
cons: It is definitely a corporate environment. This means, lots of meetings, lots of red tape, slow to react to market or implement change. Some bureaucracy and politics.

pros: Many. I left a union job to work there. They were safer than the union job, had better benefits and paid a lot better for easier tasks. Also more and better advancement opportunities. Lots of chances to work OT. I wish they hadn't sold us to another company.
cons: In my case a very long drive made the 12 hours shifts very hard. The insurance companies were't real great, especially the one that handled medical leave and stuff like that. Sometimes too much OT.  Now the plant is sold to another company that isn't as concerned with safety.

review_title: International Papers treated me with respect upon my leaving the company due to a downsizing of workforce.
pros: Since leaving the employment of the IP, I keep in touch through the Quarter Century Club, miscellaneous doings provided by the mill, monthly mill update newsletter, and just simply going back to the mill for a visit.  I have been treated with respect there at the mill since by all.
cons: The only "con" I have at this time is the fact that I lost the direct communication between myself, my fellow workers, and management.

review_title: Solid company, solid people, reasonable expectations
job_title: SAP BW Developer in Memphis, TN
pros: (For the IT org): Really solid training opportunities, good onboarding, good company culture, truly decent and basically good colleagues.  The comp, benefits, vacation, etc., are fairly standard.  Start before New Years, and you'll pick up nearly a full year toward your vacation increase at 5 years (effectively waiting only 4 years to get that extra week off).  IP is a steady and predictable employer, and managers generally do their best to ensure a happy, healthy workforce.  If you're willing to go out on the limb, branch out and learn a new position, you will usually be encouraged.  They're big enough to absorb your vacancy, meaning you're usually 'releasable' to another manager for internal moves, and standouts are recognized.  Shared Services model in IT allows if not encourages cross-pollination and syntopical learning.  You can be silo'd if you choose to be, or you can float positions every couple of years if you like.  It is unlikely that a solid worker would be downsized, as efforts are made to retain 'people', not just positions.  I had an excellent experience at IP, and would return w/o hesitation if the circumstances making that feasible arose.
cons:
If you really dig in and stick to a particular specialty, then advancement can be slow.  In big, stable companies, many other employees realize when they have it good as well, so without standout performance or a few lateral moves (to round out technical and business experience), advancement might take a while.
IF an individual thrives in a churning environment, then a smaller company with less process and planning might be preferred.  The truly restless acheiver might feel stagnate, but again, a change of position and new learning is one way to keep things interesting w/o changing companies.  IP is big enough to sustain some employee drift within the organization.  If I had it to do over, I would have 'drifted' through more roles.

review_title: Probably great environment for aged workers, not necessarily millenials
pros: If you want a place to play it safe with your career, then you've found your match.  It's not necessarily an exciting industry but at least you know the company is stable, the pay is decent (not to be confused with fair), you'll get a full range of benefits (not the best, but not the worst either), tuition reimbursement, processes are centralized and automated, and career, learning, leadership training, and travel opportunities exist.  If you work at corporate, there are even greater perks such as drawings for attending arena events like NBA games and major concerts or getting classroom projects sent to your child's school like watching butterflies grow or magazine subscriptions.
cons:
I felt like the company bullied Memphis when it threatened to leave the city unless it extended a tax benefit it had been receiving for 20 years. As someone who remembers attending school without air conditioning, that tax revenue from this multi-billion dollar company was greatly missed by the city's school system, yet the company will like to tout its $1-2M charitable donations per year to local organizations.  

After getting it's way and expanding it's HQ, you would think maybe an onsite daycare or pumping rooms would have been included as part of the plan with what more modern-engaged companies are doing, but maybe that's a symptom of the leadership being mainly baby-boomers.  

Also, a lot of the field locations are in the boondocks. So for younger employees, the prospect of spending three or more years of your best years in a place that lacks basic recreation or the potential for finding a partner becomes bleak no matter how much they pay you.  

If you aren't careful, you will notice that IP will slowly, but surely become your life. Meanwhile, piece by piece you will have given up the parts of your life that made you who you are.  It's a lot of people there that have spent their entire careers at the company so it's all they know.  As a result, if you have an existing, continual commitment in your life that conflicts with work arrangements, these types of employee feel like you just need to give up what it is you've always done before you got there because IP is all that matters and there should be not flexibility on its part. 

At IP, you get sold the mantra of infinite possibilities regarding career opportunities.  However, what they don't tell you is that at the end of the day, they will place you where they want you to go when they want you to go there.  So that means even if there's an opportunity available for which you qualify, you may not get it because your manager considers you to be non-releasable.  There also isn't a whole lot of credence given to your experience gained outside of the company.  It's almost as if what you had done before doesn't matter because they didn't see you do it there.

review_title: Under recognized company, great place to work.
pros: Strong company, good people, good plan for future success.  Of course the paper business isn't the most exciting field in the world, but International Paper is very focused on technology to get ahead of the competition.  Of all paper companies, IP is certainly the most advanced.
cons: Not a technology company.  Not a lot of room for growth in IT unless you are willing to relocate.  IT is sometimes seen as a necessary evil, mostly from small people on the inside, like local controllers and plant managers.  People at the site level have not yet recognized how to use technology to it's advantage.

pros: Great opportunity to become a versatile asset to IP and any other organization in your future endeavors. Ample training that can be tailored to your career path. Lots of opportunity for growth within the company.
cons: Requires multiple/random late nights and weekend duty. Although the company as a whole is top-tier, the Bogalusa location has some major holes when it comes racial inequality (just look at the turn over rate for minorities in salary positions). This is done by keeping 1 or 2 minorities engaged and screwing the rest, may be due to the culture of the city and mill (google it).

review_title: Bittersweet Experience. Management Could Use Revamping
pros: Great perks such as giveaways. Staff is really nice and works well as a team. Will go above and beyond to do a good job and take care of the customer.
cons: Management can be disconnected with daily activities of employees and processes. Systems are not efficient making it difficult to perform duties timely. Very bureaucratic, tough to be heard by management. Promotions and compensation aren't always fair. HR not approachable.

job_title: SAP Basis Administrator in Memphis, TN
pros: Invests in Information Technology internally with data center and employees in a time where out sourcing and hosting is thriving.
cons: Salary and merit increases are low but the cost of living in Memphis is also low justifying there reasoning.  The economy is still recovering at this time so merit raises can get better. Equipment is old and CRT rather than LCD are still used.  No head sets and shabby offices for the IT people.

review_title: If you're an outsider forget career advancement
pros: Pay and benefits, multiple career path options (by management choice), solid financial stability.
cons:
Redundant meetings with no results, slow decision making process. 

Engagement is lackluster, middle and upper level management do not engage employees. Managers are to worried about their next "opportunity" in making decisions, versus what's best for the future of the company.

If your hired in from the outside it's very hard to progress in this organization.

review_title: International Paper is a good company to work for
pros:
Safety Driven - they genuinely care about employee safety and will change processes to ensure it.
Union friendly - organized collective bargaining agreements are not a sin.
Opportunity for advancement - you move as far as you want. Work hard!
Fair salary and benefits which are competitive with industry.
Work-Life balance is pretty good.
cons:
Risk averse - very difficult to procure capital for improvements, especially if you are in a static or declining market sector. Prefers stability and the status quo as opposed to being first to market or a maverick.
Large bureaucracy - paper mills like to generate paperwork.
Medical benefits suffer weak packages along with most American businesses.

pros: pays well for a factory, co workers are great . insurance is so so. close to home for me . i myself enjoy working in a printing enviroment.
cons: managment team is very contridictive and confusing . they say safety above all else but hurry up. that makes no sense to me. they never follow their own rules and they  change rules to suit their own agenda.

pros: Contributions to school loans though I never saw the payments applied by the government.
cons: Discrimination, minimalization, mismanagement of resources, devaluation as a human if not on lead team, group think, people allowed to pretend to shoot you in hallway after saying " now you have a target on your head" and HR said, " what do you want me to do about it?"

review_title: Nice place to work if you like working!
job_title: Assistant Machine Operator in Salinas, CA
pros:
Lots of overtime available if you are up for it. They'll work you, thats for sure...

 Benefits are good, but seems you got to pay for lot of the insurance now. Not sure if the student loan repayment plan works for us on the "floor", but Im trying to utilize that currently ($9,000 lifetime contribution).

Decent pay for the requirements they want met. Where else can you get into a high paying job with a High School diploma? (I have a degree and other things, but still work here over a office cubical job...)

Best union I've been in by far. Ok work environment.
cons:
Company goes by seniority, so you may get forced to do lots of overtime. Vacation and other perks go to those with more seniority. Beginning out you usually are at the Cascaders/Waxers.  Out of the mid sized groups they hire at times only a few hard working people last. 

Its a dangerous job in some respects, watch where you stick your hands!

Jan-Feb are slow months with less work. 

You get stories from the old timers of what they used to offer and it seems we get less these days...For example; Im not sure the pay increases are beating inflation...

review_title: Not the best place to work
pros:
Union
Pay is okay not great
cons:
Management is poor
Moral is lacking
Extremely high turnover rate
Short breaks
Either very hot or cold in the plant depending on weather
Six day work weeks
Short notice on working weekends (sometimes 7 day work weeks)
Everything is broken and they don’t fix it
Nasty inside (ink, dust, glue & trash everywhere)
Vacation is a joke, takes takes 8 years to only get three weeks & 3 years to get two weeks
Point system is very hard to go down so it racks up fast
Management doesn’t know anything about fixing or running the machines

review_title: Great company, needs more diversity at mid-, and senior executive levels
pros: IP has numerous opportunities if you are willing to move and can adapt to living in smaller, rural locations. The Memphis headquarters provides a broad range of jobs and young professionals with drive will typically excel and be recognized. Compensation is above average for the industry.
