cons: Bureaucracy is still an issue, though it improved over the time I worked there. Career paths are relatively specific and those who do not get experience in manufacturing, may find it hard to advance to senior levels.

pros: Overtime if you like working a lot.
cons:
The baler job is repetitive  and hard on your back and shoulders.  Management takes short cuts with lesser quality of paper used to produce bags which frequently break in the machines pushing back production then forcing people to work overtime during the week and work on Saturdays. 

Buena Park facility is small and no room for advancement from the baler job. There is no internal transfer opportunities from one facility to another. If you see a job you are interested in at another location you have to apply for it in the same manner as a non-employee. Also some locations are union and some aren't.

review_title: My time at International Paper was bittersweet. I worked with some very talented people, but was overqualified.
pros:
They take care of and care about their employees. They work with you if you are having personal issues.
For the most part they listen to their employees concerns and ideas. 
Their pay is above avg. for the position regionally and nationally.
cons:
There is a lot of red tape to get anything accomplished.
They are not narrow minded but they have the tendency to get tunnel vision and refuse to cut losses when better options are presented. Especially in IT. 
Starting off entry level IT there are very few options for advancement.

pros: Extremely competitive pay for the industry. Decent amount of upward mobility near term, endless amount if you're in for the long haul. The vast majority of management positions, entry level through senior, are held by employees within 10 years of retirement. Promotes from within. Very few management positions filled via external recruiting.
cons: Promotions are not always performance based. Who you know overrides what you know. Very traditional "old school" company with an aged workforce. Slowly becoming more progressive but still a decade behind companies of comparable size/revenue. Locations in every state in the US but all senior management positions located in Memphis.

pros:
IP calls its Technical Support Staff ITCS.  I worked for the manufacturing division which is very laid back.  We had some general flex time as long as staff was in the office from 7-6. This meant that some of us came in from 6-3 and others 9-6.  it was very nice and no questions were ever asked provided you were productive.  The company is very respectful and open minded to solutions I had many opportunities to utilize my specialize to create innovative solutions that were out of the box for IP at the time.  It isn't the most bleeding edge work in the world, but I found my time there very relaxing unless a critical problem arose and I was always given plenty of compensation for over-time

This is a great company to work for long term. Lots of movement potential and ability to work all over the world if you move towards management and financials.
cons:
IP is a very large very old company.  I can't complain enough about the entrenchment that goes on in management.  The problem with ITCS is that they are a cost center for the manufacturing decision they work and even though they pretend to have a chain of command I can't count the times a Division manager went around 3 levels of management to talk directly to me about a problem. 

I was always very uncomfortable in this situation, not because I couldn't handle the pressure from engineering, but because I would regularly get told by my own bosses not to directly speak to these individuals.  I found the management on my side to over react to small complication instead of seeking advise from those actually aware of the circumstance.

As a large corp you will be subjected to what ever management buzz course is being forced on your team for the year.  Be prepared to enter the world of office space when dealing with them directly.  This may be worse now that ITCS has moved across the street from Corp HQ.

review_title: Alot to work on but overall not a bad company
pros:
Always room for overtime opportunities.
Millwide and departmental training.
Safety is the number #1 key for IP as a whole.
Advancement  opportunities are given to those who are focus, dedicated, and pursuing careers.
cons:
Long hours based upon department not being fully staffed. 
Veterans afraid of change
Tier pay differences 
Work/Life balance 
High turnover rate based upon pay differences

review_title: Been a great place to work (Corporate-IT Staff)
pros:
Compensation has been very good overall. In my experience here, you get out of International Paper what you put into it. There are negative people here who complain about never getting ahead and such - but in most of those cases, they are overall very negative people and I think that will hamper you here at IP. A positive, ethical mindset and a good work ethic have allowed me to really grow at IP. The opportunity is here for those that are willing to dedicate themselves to the goal. 

At the same time, IP is *excellent* with their work/life balance. None of the other companies I have worked for even come close to IP's concern with your work/life balance. This is one of the things that really goes a LONG way to keeping me at IP.

They also actually send us to training. All companies promise to send IT to training - but in my experience, very few actually make good on this promise. IP has made good on this promise.

Very laid back environment
Excellent Management
Good compensation
Mostly good benefits
Outstanding corporate ethics and morals.
cons:
Large company - easy to get 'lost' in . This can sometimes lead to various team members taking advantage of the situation and not pulling their weight. While this does allow the more ambitious to succeed, it can also be annoying to some of the co-workers at IP.

IT staff is too tightly 'siloed' sometimes. While this does help with focused subject matter expertise, it can also lead to some tension between teams and a lack of understand of the job of peer employees.

At remote sites, career growth is not even possible to a large degree for 'corporate' employees. This is only a minor-con, depending on a person's situation. For those who do wish to move ahead with IP, they are certainly opportunities for those willing to relocate to the HQ in Memphis, TN

review_title: Competitive Salary & Benefits.  Limited advancement, obvious bias, high politics
job_title: Senior Sourcing Manager in Memphis, TN
pros: Competitive Salary - Benefits of holidays and vacation. 401K & retiree benefits. High performing colleagues.
cons: No advancement in 10+ years. Constant fear of layoffs and pay cuts. Hiring & Promotion Bias, highly political. Expensive Benefits. Mature Product and Industry - very risk averse, lacking in creativity, but top notch processes.

pros: Good People and sometimes a good work environment
cons: micro-management, "good old boy" mentality, no rhyme or reason why people get promoted to Senior or Director levels. It is all about who you know. People with no skills often promoted.

review_title: Decent company but upward mobility depends heavily on your manager and area
job_title: SAP Business Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: Decent benefits, flexible hours, generally motivated coworkers who care about customer needs
cons: Project managers and others want quick turnaround on implementations but blame you later when sustainable process had no time to develop under their deadlines.  Highly political culture with obvious back-scratching and favoritism.  Management speaks of "infinite" career possibilities but if your direct manager has no pull or drive, you're not going anywhere.

pros: Good benefits: Health, dental, EAP.  Salaries are higher than the national average.  I liked that fact that IP does give back to the community.
cons: Little sharing of information by management which results in a lack of clear direction as to what is expected.  Limited resources to meet goals assigned.

job_title: Machine Operator in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: good pay most employees were good to work with
cons: Management rushed training thru because they didn't have an operator then wondered why their numbers were down?? wonder why? supervisors are not connected to employees and only want numbers. Union, has its good and bad, the bad is they have an employee who is protected by the union they need to get rid of, even the union members no this employee does not get along with others. Lots of overtime when your a new employee sometimes its not necessary but supervisors like testing new employees.

review_title: large multinational with steady work and good leaders
pros:
Through the recent recession, employees were still given raises and cost of living wage increases. The company has recently refocused attention on core highly profitable long term businesses - making boxes for example and has become a world leader in this market and others. 
The company has been around for a long time (over 100 years) and is likely to be around for a lot longer. If you are interested in a large multinational with slow and steady growth, this is it. 

Mr. Faraci is in touch with his Memphis employees and is leading the company in the right direction. He took a very bold step in raising cash and taking on substantial debt to purchase a division from Weyerhaeuser but I believe that it was the right decision for the company.
cons:
This is low profit margin manufacturing large multinational company. 
Therefore there are many layers of management, too many useless and duplicate reports to do and other seemingless foolish administrative tasks that are not apparently useful to those working in the trenches. 
For similar reasons the company wants to justify every project and watches it's money very closely. 
Changes have to regarded 
Mid level managers may be under utilized and therefore have time to micromanage. Some employees, due to the size of the company, and a somewhat lax management attitude in some areas, feel that they can get away with not working. They may in the short term but International Paper will terminate them eventually (may take years) .  
Corporate at time's seems to kowtow to businesses units and manufacturing facilities, taking the attitude that if they say they have to have then they must be .
Too many "diverse" employee's in positions that they are unqualified and unsuited for. 
In some areas I have witness'ed a cliques led by managers lead to incometence being ignored.
Many employees know "the system " is broken and dont try to attempt to fix it any more and instead just allow it continue by lying about others performance or by finding another way to accomplish a task.
Thus failures are glossed over and allowed to continue. 

The company continues to pay lip service to environmental causes and in some cases is hypocritical.
For example the company will say one thing, and do another : it has an impressive media campaign that printing on paper is better than emailing yet internally has diverted all paper notices to email versions. 
Large office buildings within Memphis, could and should have been made green decades ago (solar panels) , an investment that would have paid for itself already. 
Company does not internally recycle cans, glass or plastic . Nor does it lead such recycling programs within the community.  
The company has reduced it's north american land holdings, avoiding the responsibility of land stewardship while at the same time promoting such stewardship.

The company continues to off shore as much work as possible. The US staff continue to drive the work but understand less and less as they have a hands off attitude and become more and more project managers. This results in systems which no one understands 2 years after building, and which often do not work. 

Corporate divisions such as Human Resources and IT are understaffed and have insufficient resources, leading to long lag times or no response.

review_title: This is a very good place to work.
pros: This company really cares about safety. They have good benefits and base salary at plants by local market. Some plants are union, but non-union plants usually get offered same negotiated benefits.
cons: Plant attendance policies vary by plant, so there are no set company wide policies regarding attendance and discipline, which can lead to peer review issues.

pros: Good pay and plenty of challenges to tackle. Company culture will completely back safety concerns and provide adequate capital for issues
cons: Lots of hours and usually complexed or regional for safety spreading things thin. Work life balance is not good, too many tasks for one person to complete or delegate properly without higher authority than position allows.

review_title: "Old" Company in More Ways Than One
job_title: Process Improvement Manager in Morristown, TN
pros:
Good retirement package.
Lots of corporate emphasis on safety.
Lots of locations if you want to move around within the company.
cons:
Company is an old company in an old industry and hasn't had to change much over the years. 
Entrenched unions in most locations - some locations with better relationships and some locations horrid. 
Leadership near the top of the organization (like EHS leadership) are way overkill on micromanaging lower-level leaders. Ability of lower leaders to tailor processes to their facilities so they actually work is stifled. 
So much paperwork and redundant effort to meet corporate requirements that it's hard to actually meet the spoken expectation of being on the floor with your people. Real expectations vs imaginary expectations.
Work/life balance is horrid in many locations. Salaried employees get paid based on 49hr work weeks, but are often expected to work 6-7 days a week in practice - averaging 60-80hrs in many positions. Often-times hourly work the same, but even overtime pay comes at a cost to their personal lives - voluntary or not.
The older-in-age management often have antiquated expectations of work-ethic where your work is your #1 loyalty and you will come in in the middle of the night and every weekend if we tell you to. This has had a widespread effect on company-wide culture. This will not work with younger generations in future decades - company needs to adapt to the times if they want to be successful.

pros: practice diversity in hiring key positions, promote safety and a healthy work environment, ability to have upward mobility, good interaction between departments, health benefits, good 401K program
cons: asked to do more with less (less support personnel, less tools to work with), too many projects and not enough internal support to see them fully develop

review_title: It is an okay place for stress free work
job_title: IT Business Consultant I in Atlanta, GA
pros: Less stress for average sklled person. Benefits are good for the region and industry. Good place for beginners to build job skills.
cons: Growth opportunity is only based on communication skills and political savvy people. Technically skilled people in IT are not reviewed based on performance. Even if you save tons of money on projects, there is no payback to the contributor. There are plenty of managers ready to take credit for the work.

pros: Pay is very competitive overall. While I might be able to make more 'cash' at some other places, it wouldn't make up for the stability that IP has offered me, along with the total benefits package. Their Retirement plans are good, health benefits are decent, and there are many other benefits outside of these realms. I have actually gotten training, whereas many companies will promise training - IP delivered. There are a lot of good people to work with as well, I have had no major issues with management and even the 'high level' mangers are approachable, for the most part. From my experience, upper management is as in touch with their employees as they can be in an organization of this size. Outside of entire facility closure, I haven't seen any layoffs and even in those cases, the chances of being able to relocate (if willing) and maintain a position with IP have been good to excellent. In most areas there is little outsourcing and much of that is 'temp to hire' - and they actually do hire in many of those cases, if you do a good job. Additionally; while there is some debate overall on the subject, for the most part - hard work is rewarded. Very good life/work balance - when I needed time off the most, it wasn't even questioned - a manager 3 levels above me told me to take the time I need for my family.
cons: Large environment creates many 'work silos' - keeping you in a narrow scope of responsibilities, that can be a 'con' to a degree since you do not get much experience outside of your 'specialty'. It is also easy to get 'lost in the crowd' if you aren't a very assertive personality. Change is slow in coming and there can often be a 'hurry up and wait' dynamic on projects. Promotions can be limited, depending on the facility you are located at. the overly ambitious may not find it the best environment for quick advancement.

review_title: My experience has had many ups and downs.  Mostly ups.  My main dissatisfaction lies with advancement opportunities.
pros: The best reason to work for International Paper is the compensation. IP pays a living wage that allows its employees to make a comfortable living.
cons: The major downside to working at International Paper is the lack of career paths and advancement opportunities. Specifically, the policy that allows managers to prevent employees from applying for internal positions without their permission.

pros: Very friendly people, lots of personal development opportunities, emphasis on managers caring for their employees.
cons: Certain "favorite" people get promoted when much more qualified people are more deserving. It is like they must meet a quota of certain age, sex, race, etc., instead of promotions based on merit.

pros:
Started innovation which is slowly making headway.
Started Diversity and Inclusion - 
Good Pay for the job
cons:
Bad benefits
Company cares more about Core employees than long term employees
Promotions to senior level - not going to happen. The only way this will happen is if you are on a managed move list or have a mentor in director or above level (or you are Core).
Promotion into senior manager roles is not based on experience and performance.

review_title: Great company in a unique industry
pros: IP is a fantastic company to work for. There's plenty of opportunity to succeed if you're willing to put forth the effort. Those who do good work are often recognized with opportunities for advancement. The pay is on par with the industry and high for those living in Memphis, which has an incredibly low cost of living.
cons: Office politics can get in the way at the corporate office, but that can be said for any large corporation. Decision making can be a challenge, which causes unnecessary and frustrating delays in some circumstances.

pros: Great place to work. I learned a lot of good skills in operation of DCS and related equipment. I worked in the Power house and was treated much better there than I was in the Converting area.
cons: When International Paper is done with a Plant they shut it down, just like they did my plant, and all the rest. It doesn't mater if the plant is productive or not. Don't waste your time at a paper plant, paper is on its way out, you will just be looking for a job when you are older, it was nice while it lasted but it didn't last long   enough.

job_title: EHS Safety Manager in Courtland, AL
pros:
IP is a large corporation so there are almost limitless resources available if you know where and how to ask. The IP pay scale is commensurate with other similar companies. 
There are some great people working at IP.
cons:
Though the pay scale is commensurate with other companies, getting a promotion is usually very difficult. Like a lot of large companies where employees make good salaries, there is a lot of jealousy and envy amongst the employees about what each other is making. Who tells them? Instead of looking for very talented help and rewarding them for a job well done, they reward mediocrity with their sliding, bell curve based salary determination scale. If an employee has been doing excellent work for numerous years, they may get an increase in salary of up to 5%. (though it is usually between 0 & 1%, like .47% for example.) 
On the other hand, if an employee has been borderline at performing their job for most of their career, and they suddenly do their job, they get rewarded with the maximum 5% increase in salary! Where is the incentive for the high performers to keep producing? It's the proverbial story of the horse pulling the cart and the one tied to the back of the cart. The horse pulling the cart gets whipped if they suddenly let up, but the one following behind the cart doing nothing to help pull the cart, just keeps getting fed, watered and groomed!

job_title: Senior Transportation Planning Analyst in Columbia, SC
pros: Compettive pay is about all I can say about IP but only paid once a month which sucks!
cons: Terrible place for African Americans to work and try to advance. Very good ole boy environment and political to limiting your future. "Infinite possibilities" is  blatant lie!

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Morgantown, WV
pros: Family oriented company with long-tenured senior leaders who willingly interact and want to mentor new talent. Develop talent within and there are unlimited opportunities if you are willing to work hard and communicate openly with your manager.
cons: It depends on the business division in which you are placed, but a good amount of travel is usually involved since HR is very lean. This allows for a greater scope and experiences, but can be tiring.

pros: They are very big on people development, and have a lot of training opportunites for leadership and development.  It is a good team environment. Even though you may work in a different department, there are many company activities where you get to know others at the company and are able to network. There are so many opportunities around the United States, so if you are mobile, there are unlimited opportunites on positions.
cons: Some positions could be long hours during the month... especially finance around month-end

pros: Excellent starting pay.  Lots of overtime. Good benefits package from Teamster Union.  All Federal Holidays off with pay.  Friendly people
cons: Union shop so vacations and upward mobility is by seniority.  Floating holidays blacked out May through September.  Very hot working environment in summer.  Draconian attendance policy has been relieved somewhat by mandatory payed sick leave law

review_title: Decent Benefits, Will Work You to Death if You Let Them
pros: Tons of opportunities to move up with large amount of workforce retiring over the next several years. Good 401k match. Lots of great training and learning opportunities if you pursue it.
cons: Will work you to death if you let them. This can vary depending upon management at each individual facility. Health insurance sucks.

review_title: Supervisors Work Many Many Hours - even in Finance
pros: Some of the people were very nice.
cons: As a Supervisor you will be expected to put in as many hours as it takes. I worked around 50 to 60 hours a week especially during budget and costing. There are many mandatory meetings you have to attend in spite of the workload you might have, further pushing your paperwork behind. The benefits are not as good as other companies, only 3 days sick leave per year, $3,000 medical deductible.  Your family has to understand your work comes first.

review_title: It has been great working here.
pros: international gives alot of training on pumps,turbines,hydr.,deffern in types of oil,belt classes,bearing classes and more have learned a lot here and got alot of exspe.
cons: they are a big company even though this plant mades alot of money they still shut it down so i would say they dont realy consider the small people that depend on it running.

review_title: NO work/life balance - Good luck planning weekends

cons: Poor management, scheduling, hiring, communication, etc has made for a long term career of missed weekends and evenings with family and friends.  Telling us at the last minute whether or not we have to work late or on weekends is completely unacceptable.   You leave employees without any true opportunity to catch their breath or have a life outside work.

pros: Decent Salary and Decent benefits
cons:
Zero work/life balance 
Work 6 to 7 days a week that you’re not told about upfront 
Cutthroat environment 
Zero employee value-doesn’t matter if you’re a production employee or management

review_title: International Paper is a great Company to be part of

review_title: Great job, always work, maybe a little too much work

pros: Excellent starting pay. Lots of overtime. Good benefits package from Teamster Union. All Federal Holidays off with pay. Friendly people

cons: Extremely warm during the summer months and a poor attendance program that is abused by some of the employees. Hard to plan weekends because of customer short notice ordering- but kind of hard to get around.

pros:
-You can always find the answers. If someone doesn't know, there is a document, or a guide, or a system in place.

-Well respected company 
-You don't get the feeling you will be stuck, the company really prides itself on endless possibilities, that's encouraging for someone who wants to grow professionally.
cons: None yet, but the one thing that sticks out to me is the lack of diversity in senior level management, communications, and government relations.

pros: Great pay, benefits above average.  Lots of opportunity to move within the company.  If you are a mediocre performer this is a steady place to work without a great deal of competition.

They are unwilling to consider any type of flexible work arrangement at all.  In general I don't think people are treated well at IP.  Their isnt much competition for top tier talent in Memphis so IP does the bare minimum. 
I

cons: IP closed the mill at the end of 2009.  The small paper machines were not competitive in the global market.  The back end of the mill was new (by industry standards, less than 10 years) and may find new life in future.

They are mostly business, accounting, and marketing types, instead of production and manufacturing experience based.

pros: Good Pay, Benefits are good, most jobs are easy work, Good Training opportunities ,overtime almost always available, Lots of Paid holidays

pros: They offer good benefits, the pay is fair, and they have gain sharing. There is also a strong push for safety and engagement.

review_title: Great company!  Really cares about you as a person!

They offer great benefits. Really helped me starting out. 

You get 1-to-1 meetings with your boss showing how far you've come and what path you are on. 

It isn't hard to be moved to different locations if you show you are a hard worker.
cons: It smells pretty bad in a Papermill. You get used to it, but the first week is hard.

review_title: International Paper is a very large company...Can get lost in the career maze.
pros: IP takes very good care of their employees and there is a lot of movement within the groups.
cons: 1930's style management, managers don't talk to workers.  Everyone is to worried what "level" they are.  Too many people means not much to do for may people.

pros: International Paper has great employee benefits.  I would highly recommend this employer, if you are interested in receiving great benefits.  Matching medical savings plan.
cons: Can be a very political environment.  Advancement may depend on who you know at International Paper.  Overall, a great place to work.

pros: Coworkers, for the most part, are treasures. Initial high pay is attractive.
cons: Really high health insurance premiums, and no vision insurance...both things are ridiculous for a company with 50k? employees.  This is NOT a 40 hr/wk job-- to do the extra things that will get you more opportunities you'll have to sacrifice time with family. And since there are people willing to do that, management expects it from everyone.

review_title: As often happens, my experiences varied tremendously according to which department I worked for.
pros: Benefits are great, and salaries, though very uneven, usually averaged to industry standards.  I was always able to work with my management, which wasn't always the case with previous companies.
cons: Communication skills with upper management reigns supreme, often to the detriment of having or properly using technical skills.  (This was true in my department, but certainly not in other departments.)

review_title: Great Company for Whom to Work
pros: Large company with lots of business entities and opportunities for growth.  Multiple facilities within a given geographic area allow the possibility transfer for upward growth.
cons: Due to the company size, the work environment can sometimes be a bit conservative or sterile.  Managers need to create a bit more of an individual facility feel as opposed to being part of the big conglomerate.

review_title: Lots of opportunity for results driven people. The tools and resources are there to succeed. Long term planning.
pros: I liked that the businesses are changing with the ever changing landscape. They have done a great job through the transformation year to set themselves up for the future. Good pay and opportunities. Cost of living in Memphis enables this to be a good opportunity for families.
cons: You must want to live in Memphis, TN. This is where the corporate office is.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Good company to work for. Care about their people. Very sustainable company. Competitive almost comprehensive medical plan.
cons: Education level of supervisors not as high as it should be. Hiring of associates and managers takes at least 3 months. Difficult interview process for current employees.

review_title: If you don't mind shift work, the pay is great!
pros: Great pay, no micro managing, great for self starters, little variation in the job duties, great team environment. Shift work if you're into it, allows for only working 15 days out of the month.
cons: little variation of job duties, shift work is not for every one, repetitive motion and processes of production can be dull.

job_title: Production Machine Operator in Streetsboro, OH
pros: Good pay! Friendly Employees & Management! Pretty easy work! Plenty of Overtime Availability! Management who actually takes employee safety very seriously
cons:
Overtime (if that’s not your thing) and working Saturdays during busy summer months.
Work environment is HOT in the summer.
Management turnover rate, for the most part management is very good and very helpful but can get a bad apple from time to time.

pros: Company does provide training, and management does care about professional development.
cons: Work/Life balance is not out there, supervisors are not compensated for the overtime and weekend hours.

job_title: Supply Chain Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros: The company is great at developing people.  It has a good value system and treats employees with respect.  The pay and benefits are good.  Plenty of opportunites to grow your career in a variety of roles.
cons: Moving up in the organization may require the ability to move several times in a career.  The work hours are typical business hours, however they are very flexible if you cannot be in the office for some reason.

pros: Pay was good, they gave out bonuses for good work.  Management kept employees informed with monthly meetings.  If you wanted overtime you could make a killing.
cons: Gossip, way too much talking about people behind their backs.  You'd think you were at a hair salon.  If you didn't want the overtime, you were out of luck if you didn't have seniority.  You basically worked 12 hours every day.

pros: Very forward thinking for the safety of their people. Nice pay for hourly employees.
cons: No upward movement, no training (if fact NO training what so ever for an HR). HR is an after thought at this company. Would not be a bad starting place for someone out of college, however after a couple of years start looking to move on elsewhere. Will hire outside the company before they will train you to advance.

review_title: Maintenance-Good paycheck,  lots of hours,  basic benies, Zero PTO
pros: A lot of OT, some good people,  not a really tough climate, help for tasks decent training in some areas
cons: No PTO and demerits for even sick non-pd time, clicky by shifts, forced OT with very little notice, can be targeted for blame and bad communication in dept

pros: Good people to work with and good company. Pay was fair and location was great. Good benefits as well
cons: As a process engineer you can expect the every day challenges that come with that title, need to be proactive and motivated to get the job done

pros: A lot of opportunity with the ability to readily transfer to other facilities. Great pay. Great benefits. Very strong and well established company with long term goals and a very solid plan.
cons: Very overworked and very under appreciated. Results are really the only thing that matter. Dedication and commitment do not carry the weight they should.

pros: very ethical company, cares about sustainability
cons: traditional industry may not sounds attractive to younger folks

pros: We are like a big family..
cons: The boss likes to micro managed.

pros: Attracts nice coworkers, always something new to do, varying duties and responsibilities, yearly performance review, good way to learn more. about other positions in the company, ability to work from home as hybrid schedule occasional days each week
cons: Turn over in management leads to changes in performance expectations, loophole where new title positions created do not have to be posted and can be handed to candidate of management choosing, Customer Service becomes a catch all for tasks not currently performed by other departments (A/R, A/P, collection research, internal training), to advance without a 4-year degree is very difficult, management would take outside applicants over internal candidates without a degree even if performance has been flawless, pay level disparity and inability for company to recognize Customer Service as more than entry level, it takes 1-2 years to be proficient in the necessary systems.

pros: My time as an AE at IP was excellent. I found the people I enjoyed engaging with the most and was able to be challenged and learn. I am sure advancement would have been in the picture had I stayed.
cons: Advancement is what you make it. If you want to go far you'll have to engage in office politics. If that isn't your thing you may have a tough time.

review_title: A good company for growth but you need to take the initiative.
pros: IP has a lot of good opportunities, it has been a place I have recommended to friends to work and several have done well and others have become stagnant and left. What I would recommend for anyone who wants to advance in this company is to be direct in what you want to do long term with your manager. Most people who struggle are waiting to be told what to do versus trying to build their careers and finding people to champion them. If you don't like networking and building bridges, IP's culture focus on relationships will be burdensome.
cons: New employees are onboarded and integrated into the company poorly. This has improved slightly in the last 2 years but many senior leaders are fixed into their mindset of you don't know anything till you have been at the company for 10+ years.

cons: Management does not care at all about their employees. If you want to works 10-12 hours a day, 6 days a week and never have any time for anything outside of work then this is the place for you

pros: If you like overtime and physically working your life away on your feet for up to 12hrs/6days a week this is it. There are some very talented people here.
cons: Revolving door of employees quitting or getting fired. Extremely loud and hot environment, frequent injuries and over micromanaged. Supervisors and management nearly constantly looking over your shoulders waiting for your task to be completed to give you another one. Work schedule is too demanding for somewhat of a life outside of work. Terrible vacation policy. Extremely expensive and weak union contract. Little to no training. Can be frustrating because the efficient good workers get grinded for more and more work, and the “lazy ones” are not held accountable for doing VERY little. People age very quickly working here.

review_title: Say goodbye to family ,friends ,hobbies or anything else that brings you joy
pros: Competitive pay ,good benefits , unlimited Squincher electrolyte beverages

Lots of hours , they demand all your time and then some, there not very flexible and have an archaic attendance policy

If you're lucky enough to land this gig , hug your children and make love your wife one last time because you will be a ghost provider from now on.

job_title: Applications Developer Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: International Paper has great management team who are supportive of their employee growth perspective. There are bonus program for level 7 employees and above starting on beginning of 2023. The 401K matchup is around 60% of your contribution up to 8% of employee's salary. There are opportunities to move around and try different group within departments and among departments and relaxing working environment
cons: They are slow adapting to the new technologies; however, they are doing great job at catching up to the new trends. The bonus program starts kind of late compared to other corporations who have done it for a long time. Relied too heavily on SAP as their main ERP software made the company slower to adapt to a new trends, and the SAP software is great, but the analytical software came with SAP are usually buggy and have quite few issues sometime with not a lot of online supporting material to research.

review_title: Pay is Acceptable, Company Culture Needs Massive Improvement
pros: Management tried to do a good job at accommodating employees in terms of needing time off for important duties, and the pay is great if you have the qualifications and even more if you have an advanced degree.
cons: Company culture is very traditional and it is as if the company refuses to navigate/conform with the current environment. It is very early 1900s. It is easy to feel like a number and a robot rather than a team member. The company cares deeply about you getting your results (which is perfectly fine) but struggles to find balance between not treating its employees like a number. I have been at the company for several years and haven't had a single conversation with upper-management, whereas at previous companies, upper-management made it a priority to at least know the names of the employees doing all of the core work. Room for upper mobility is extremely limited and it is almost as if the positions are already pre-reserved for others.

review_title: Not the Worst You Can Do
pros:
-The pay is the most significant advantage. IP does pay a living wage and there are yearly raises.
-The benefits are OK. About 3 weeks vacation plus most holidays, expensive but decent health insurance, good 401k matching.
-Not the worse way to get your food in the door for other technology positions
cons:
-International Paper's bulk of employees are very old, and so a lot of the processes, policies, and services are extremely outdated.

-You will find it VERY hard to thrive if you are not a social butterfly, a networking whiz, a previous intern, or if you don't know the right people. This is a pervasive issue company-wide but it's particularly bad in the IT department and in the Service Desk, where those liked by management will get promoted regardless of qualifications, performance, or process. I have seen people getting fired just to give the position to someone's family member. I have seen entire procedures get changed to give promotions to unqualified candidates who happen to be best friends with management. I have seen entire positions get created for no purpose other than hiring specific individuals.
-The environment within the Service Desk has eroded through the years. You will be micromanaged to extremes, you will not have many opportunities to grow or learn beyond the scope of the job, and you will see your rights and privileges diminish as months go by.

review_title: Fairer than most companies their size. Most ethical in their class.
pros:
Lots of upward mobility for the talented and politically savvy. Overall an ethical company. Salaried professionals tend to be well-paid - most other industries and especially smaller companies cannot compete with the compensation. If you are a conscientious type (look that up in the Big 5 personality traits), then you'll love and do well at this company and you'll be rewarded with promotions every 2-3 years. Conscientious types tend to be less creative and more industrious in their work habits. 

This company also takes safety very seriously at the corporate and mill-leadership levels.
cons:
As with any large corporation, there is entirely too much red tape. This comes with having 50K+ employees so this isn't a personal strike against IP as company but its just a common characteristic found in companies of this magnitude. The company has international agendas that it panders to, namely with the UN, WEF, etc. so that may or may not be a problem for some. In many settings, there is pressure to conform and a fear of speaking up and telling the truth the way you see it, especially if it goes against the prevailing narrative.

Lastly, more about the creativity piece - This company is very mature commodities-based company and therefore has less need for someone to re-invent the wheel for them. Creativity is difficult to express in such rigid, mature industrial processes such as making paper for the largest paper company in the world. If having a creative role is your cup of tea, consider looking for a company that is still young in their business life cycle and who has a demand for innovation on a much shorter time frame. Those industries will be more appreciative of creative types (openness to experience). Again, go look up what a creative person is like in the Big 5 personality traits and go listen to Jordan Peterson on the subject of corporations and openness vs. conscientiousness. That will give you a better idea of what you're up against with this industry. If you are a creative type and you choose to work at IP, my recommendation is to have a creative hobby on the side that you take very seriously so that you can satisfy your innate desire to create something new. It is my belief that the company will fail to offer adequate opportunities to be creative - this ties back in to the company being too big for its own good and has too much red tape - such size and red tape limits how much creativity the company can entertain and the margins are too low and the stakes are too high for them to be taking large risks with paradigm-shifting ideas. 

Consider yourself adequately warned!

pros: Pay is great, and some hourly employees are great folks.
cons: Management sucks. Particularly the management. I worked 8 days in a row 12 he says. I was averaging 55 hrs a week not because I asked for it but because they were short handed. I had a dental surgery on a day I was not scheduled to work. My boss called and asked if I could work on that night( my surgery in the morning). I said I could and started getting ready however I was told that you should always get a lot of sleep before surgery. Now with that in mind I was suppose to get off at 7 am and had surgery at 8:30am. So I called my boss and told him he said well work untill 3 am I never said yes. I worked 3 days after that and was supposed to be off for 3 days. But they fired an employee so he asked me to work I said yes. Friday a supervisor seen I was vomiting and wanted to send me home. I text my boss told him that a supervisor was sending me home because I was vomiting but I didn't want to go because I was scared it would be held against me. I never heard back so I went home. Saturday I was sick and Sunday on the way to work about 15 min before shift start my boss finally text me back( after I had called and text all day seeing I were suppose to work) telling me no not tonight. The next day I was called and fired for the dentist thing. This was a week after that had happened and I had worked days before that.

review_title: Great Feeder Company for the rest of the Industry
pros:
Very Safety conscious company. Possibly too many safety rules. 

They have a fantastic program for recruiting and training new engineers out of College. (REACH)

Lots of training and advancement opportunities if you are motivated in your first few years. Very equal treatment at some mills for men and women.

They have a great 401k match and company contribution for retirement.

If you are an engineer they will give you lots of opportunities for growth even outside of your area of study if you are interested.
cons:
After you are established in your career, it's not terribly different than other companies so you see a lot of people jumping ship between 3-10 years.
 
They do not do cost of living adjustments in the mill system to compensate for differences between the middle of Alabama and the West Coast but they do this in the Box Plant system. It make no sense!

The insurance is very expensive and Cigna coverage is not very good. Most people were on spouse's insurance if that was an option. For 2 people I was paying over $700/month! No option for employee+1. 

Still a male dominated industry and not much being done to allow women to succeed long term in the field.

Eventually the arbitrary requirements they have rolled out throughout the company will hinder them from competing with their competitors.

pros: -The pay...kind of. Not really. Compared to other paper companies, they pay is mediocre at best. So no pros, honestly.
cons:
-Mediocre/expensive benefits that you pay for BEFORE you get them.
-Hilariously Inept Management...they create problems where there don’t need to be any, refuse to perform maintenance until the machines break, encourage employees to snitch/backstab, and blame production employees for anything and everything that goes wrong.
-Extraordinarily hostile environment. Again, everything is your fault. Even if there isn’t any work to be done, you will be told you are not working fast/hard enough. Expect to be harassed almost constantly.
-monotonous, unfulfilling work. The most boring, repetitive job I have ever had.
-HR will not help you. With anything.
-Weak Union. Expect little to no help if you have issues with management.
-Horrible schedules.
-General incompetence on the part of management. Somehow, in the middle of a paper bag shortage, they couldn’t figure out how to make the plant break even, let alone turn a profit. It takes effort to fail that hard. Naturally, this was the fault of the production employees.

job_title: Assistant Machine Operator in Louisville, KY
pros: Decent hourly base pay, and it's a union.
cons:
High stress environment, one or 2 good managers but most play the favoritism game. Overtime is ridiculous, when people on other shifts call in, you can be forced to work overtime on their position, last minute notification. Countless times I was notified 5 mins before my shift ended, that i was forced to stay over another 4 hrs because someone else called in. If you say you cant stay, you get pointed for it. Why should i take responsibility for other employees call ins? It's not my company to run. You guys figure it out.
Absolutely no work life balance, you practically live there, especially if you're maintenance.

review_title: Comparatively the best in-class work environment and compensation
pros:
This review ONLY applies to the fiber-side of procurement (both in Virgin and Recovered Fiber sectors of the industry):

-Excellent compensation (in the fiber procurement sector) EXCLUDING health insurance 
-They make reasonable accommodations (i.e. work from home) 
-Highly professional culture - low occurrence of low-class/ inappropriate behavior
cons:
-Is overly politicized and fairly easy to commit career suicide - sometimes without even realizing you did! You need to have tact & be familiar with the skills associated with the "dog & pony show". A silver tongue w/ a can-do and positive attitude are required for most people to advance to certain levels in the company. Just being good at your job is not in itself enough to soar with this company - you have to develop your soft skills although there have been a few old-school hold-outs that made it pretty far up in the ranks prior to the progressive HR agenda being implemented. Just like ANY OTHER BIG CORPORATION, there are unspoken social rules that are unethical & hypocritical (double-standard) that one must play by in order to advance IN CERTAIN AREAS of the company. Not all areas require these unspoken soft skills to advance consistently. 
-Health Insurance benefits are scant while premiums are high (this may not be a criticism of the company benefits as much as it is a criticism of the current health insurance and medical regulatory environment. Packages are largely unchanged from when I started back in 2012 - but what did change was the premiums doubled between 2012 - 2018 for family while the coverage remained stagnant. Obamacare is to blame for the premiums while IP is to blame for not adapting and remaining competitive by carrying the weight of the premiums - further premium hikes now get passed to the employee. 
-Match pay on 401K is marginal - average is around $.60 on the dollar for the first 8% (it isn't terrible but I've seen considerably better)

review_title: Good for the short term our breaking into the industry.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Federal Way, WA
pros:
Pay is livable.
Wonderful co-workers that you will become attached to like family and won't want to leave, even when the environment becomes toxic.
Flex start time, based on work.
Free coffee.
Student loan assistance.
cons:
Business direction is shaky. The division I was in had more turnover (corporate, management and onsite positions) this past year than I have seen in 5 years of working for this company. Corporate is constantly moving their employees around between businesses or location sites. Each corporate leader is looking to implement different standards and goals, so sites keep having to change business direction. Recently there were two projects that were bringing in revenue (and had potential to bring in much more if marketing developed better customer leads) that were ended. During tough fiscal times that the industry is going through, one must wonder why these projects were ended. 

Direct leadership are over worked because they often have their own project work to do, typically manage other people and their careers, as well as continually having to take on new duties since this location is in a hiring freeze but has had several retirements and turnover. They will toe the corporate line and not go to bat for you if it means rocking the boat.

Communication is awful at pretty much every level. Between project managers, scientists and technicians. Between management and everyone else. There is too ambiguity and inconsistency. This in the end can be expensive because if work is done incorrectly, you have wasted hours and materials. Much information has to pass through the rumor mill instead of formal communication to all employees. Creates mistrust and misunderstandings, has been compounded by CoVid-19 while 50-66% of the building are working from home.

Few opportunities for for tangible growth (raises and promotions are far and few between, even for valuable employees/high performers). It is often that you are presented with "growth and leadership" opportunities, however, this is their way of adding responsibilities to your job that expand your capabilities but will not be financially compensated for. Sure, you will get the annual raise, but to move through PLs takes promotions. In 5 years, I have only seen 4 promotions. All except one of which were for people that had been there 7-13 years and had been waiting 5-7 of them for a promotion. Bonus program is only available to those at high scientist and management level. 

There are more than a few examples where technicians are doing scientist work yet have not been formally promoted. Those onsite are relied up now more than ever to take care of things that are not their responsibility. CoVid-19 has allowed for many of the scientist and project managers to "work from home" and some have become disconnected from the onsite work. For example, there are certain scientist that expect next day or two turn around for their work, just because they decided to finally submit something (because they are coming up against a deadline and realized they need some data to present) when there is work already in process to be completed. 

Clique culture. Most of these employees have worked together for 10+ years and are able to regale you with stories of the "good old days". Though most are friendly, I have seen cases of when people just don't fit in and can lead to being black balled out of working in an area or a project. Beware the bullies and steamrollers! If you're into that, manipulation of the "right" people will work here. You will find that if you target and befriend highly influential people, it will put you in a position to be treated favorably. Some managers will not evaluate you by your work ethic but instead how you the façade that is presented. 

Instead of productivity and quality in which one completes their work, there is a heavy emphasis on networking and attending all of the non-essential meetings and activities. There is no possible way to do your job successfully and attend everything. People who are in attendance of everything are those who want to 1. avoid their actual work responsibilities, 2. brown nose to the "right" people to be noticed. 

Company values (like safety) tend towards being just lip service with no action, particularly if the price tag to upkeep their values is too expensive. The only safety officer onsite had their position eliminated. The nurse that was contracted onsite 3 days a week, no longer is available, instead there is a virtual nurse. Despite having 3 medical incidents onsite within the past year. AND weathering a pandemic. Also, due to the decreased capacity of the building, they are waiting to re-sign their evening custodial service. We have just one (amazing, kind and hard working) custodian during the work hours that covers cleaning and disinfecting the high touch areas AND daily cleaning. Keep in mind that the square footage of the building did not change.

The facility I transferred to was the Franklin VA Mill which had previously been closed. I worked there for a year on several projects to change the facility to a Mill that makes Fluff. I had the worst boss ever. He was to busy to assign me projects so sent me out to hunt for my own. When any project did run into trouble he offered no assistance nor advise. I was treated like a REACH Engineer even though I came in knowing all the tools and demonstrating all the ability to successfully execute projects. I was given no credit for the numerous projects I had completed successfully but given all the credit when a small issue arose, which I fixed as well. review_title: Company with many strengths, but limited by the politic and work systems
pros:
Opportunities are plentiful for the candidate that is willing to relocate and amenable to playing the political game.  In an ideal world, the pay has great upside potential.  

The company, as a whole, is well positioned to continue to be a leader in the global paper products industry.
cons:
Politics and management style impact your career, income, and job satisfaction.  Two employees with nearly identical skill sets, working for two different managers in two different geographies will have two completely different opportunities.  In one region, management promotes, recognizes, and rewards good performance.  In the second region, the management makes decisions which limit the employees success, but blames the employee for poor performance. The management in region two is less likely to recognize good performance. 

Having a manager that is willing to share the credit for good performance and recognizes good performance to mid-level and top level managers, is the difference between an employee that will be promoted, and an employee that will become stagnant and unproductive.

Overall, the people at IP are fantastic.  Safety is #1 here. Retirement program is company matched 401k options.
cons: Health insurance is a little high, although a free program exists within the company that reduces your monthly costs. I have not yet used the insurance so I cannot speak to the quality of Cigna. The locations of many International Paper mills are something to be desired. Some mills are closer to cities with amenities, but a lot of far away from places you would prefer to live. IP recently did away with their pension program. Some systems are old, but are always being improved.

pros: Pays a salary that is good for the area.
cons: Management is incompetent, dishonest, bureaucratic, lazy, unprofessional, blamers, ....

pros: great benefits great pay great people to work with
cons: high management turnover, heat,cold, too many hours

pros: Steady work, good health benefits
cons: Lots of overtime, gets hot in the summer

pros: Respect for People and good work life balance
cons: cumbersome internal procedures and some loss of efficiency

pros: Get plenty of hours and plenty of time work to do.
cons: Color really matters... Never have time for anything but to work and they treat there employee like crap. Then if you have a problem ( especially involving one of there friend or family member) which they tell you to address them with but really if you do you are just making it worser for yourself.  They only care for the work for the company. The people at this company is very sexist and racist. This company really needs to be under investigation. Then when it's time for you to have your day off they make you work while they at home. They don't care even if it a family emergency and you have proof to provide, you still stand a chance of getting fired and you are going to get pointed it doesn't matter... They only care about the job. Even in the office part there is only one black and the only way she got there was by transfer... You stand no chance to advance with this company if your not a part of them..

pros: Great money starting out and only gets bettwr
cons: DuPont swing is rough to work

job_title: Roll Stock in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Pay and pension are great.
cons: They couldn't care less about you or what you think.

review_title: I am team lead for the regional on MN
job_title: Systems Administrator & Regional Support in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Like the people I work with
cons: Low pay and too much work

pros: All good people. Good Management
cons: There are no cons I can think of.

review_title: Lost Touch With Long Term Employees
pros: Good salary and the people that work with you are friendly.
cons: Cater to college recruits (CORE). CORE is spoon fed special assignment and given positions without any experience. December we let IT staff go and then turn around and create Strategic Analyst position for someone with no qualifications and they do not post it. If you are not on the managed move list to get promoted and no one can tell you how to get on the list. Senior leaders routinely are deceptive about their motivation especially in Information Technology. Ethics is something they preach but do not practice. I have had directors and senior managers information technology lie to my face and when you show them your CSA is impacted. If you are long term employee your contribution does not count. Want a prime example, CORE have a budget, they often spend time with VP, Directors, Sr. Managers, etc. They are spoon fed positions. They get training on leadership that long term employees do not get. CORE have little experience and even if you are not accepted into because you do not meet requirements by CORE, a VP or Director can have you put into CORE. Just go look at some of the CORE GPAs.

pros: Job security, pension 401k medical dental,
cons: Sometimes too many hours. Hot in summer

pros: Great corporate culture and focus on safety
cons: Slow process of making decisions

job_title: General Labor in Kansas City, MO
pros: There is not an upside. This place is awful.
cons: The temperature inside the plant is 10 or 20 degrees hotter than outside at all times. Management treats union very poorly. Verbal abuse comes with the territory.

job_title: Paper Machine Helper in Three Rivers, MI
pros: Pay was great. Benefits were better than most places.
cons: Lots of hours. Management was decent. Fast turnover rate.

pros: Good Pay, Lots of work, Benefits, 401k Plan, Reliable
cons: Weekend work, Bad management, Long hours, Hard to progress

job_title: SAP ABAP Developer in Memphis, TN
pros: Lots of opportunities for growth and career development
cons: Large corporation - stuck in their ways

review_title: All the overtime you want, and some you don't
pros: Some of the best pay in the area, all the overtime you want you basically can write your own paycheck, if you are a good worker your fellow co workers will look out for you. When everything is running smoothly can be the easiest job in the world. SOME of management will work with you as best they can.
cons: Most of management has absolutely no clue what goes on inside the actual plant or don't care, and the few that do are hard pressed to help you because they have to kiss up to the higher ups to stay in good graces. 12 hour shifts can be long especially during upset conditions. Heavy industrial environment can be dangerous if you get careless. At my facility we are underpaid/compensated when compared to equivalent jobs at other mills. Insurance is meh. Can be called in if given enough prior notice. Shifts can change week to week ( especially for new employees) making it hard to make long term plans outside of work.

pros: I really enjoyed the job, the pay was good and I learned a lot. My immediate manager was great to work for.
cons:
They made a really hasty decision to shut down an entire mill that has always been profitable (was still profitable at the time of shut down) to send business to an over seas mill. They made a cost cutting goal for us to help the company (mind you we were still profitable)  and we doubled the cost cutting savings and everything was looking good. We were all proud of ourselves with posters plastered throughout the mill letting everyone know we exceeded our goals, then one day one of the hireups came and shut us down.

 something like this can happen at any time. As long as the International paper mill you are employed arent in the crosshairs, the job is great. but you dont have to be in bad shape to be shut down.

pros: IP is a fair & ethical company that offers a consistent and steady career advancement for those who are willing to stand out from the rest. IP has many global opportunities for those who are seasoned and offer global talent to the company. Decent benefits and opportunities to grow in both strengths and weaknesses.
cons: Iconic atmosphere of secularism, bureaucracy and political correctness. This type of culture is typically created by such large companies in effort to avoid lawsuits and hurt feelings amongst employees of different backgrounds. However, in the end it only stiffles authenticity and candidness, causing many people to feel out of place or resent the entire system as a whole since it rewards uniformity rather than originality or creativeness.

review_title: Great company. Don't start you career at corporate.
pros: IP has sent me to all parts of the US. I have worked on several different projects that allowed me to take ownership and receive credit for the work that I accomplished. IP has been understanding and supportive when I needed them to be. The pay seems to be on par with other careers. Upper management is accessible and as friendly as I would expect an executive to be. I am very satisfied working for IP.
cons: Relocation is a necessity if you want to move up in the company. You could just stay at corporate, but, unless you have prior experience in the field, you are only going to move up so far before you level out.

job_title: E and I Technician in Riverdale, AL
pros: Excellent pay for the location
cons: Work life balance and antiquated shift

pros:
The company is very large, lots of mobility, well established, training was very good. Good compensation package. Employees are well compensated too. 

Mentoring program was there but mentors need to be trained. 

They stressed safety....this was very high point for me personally. They never did anything unsafe.
cons:
There was to many layers of managers. When something needed to be reviewed it took two layers of managers above you to get it done. 

When issues would be brought to the attention of managers it was never addressed it would always be a finger pointing game. It should have been lets work together  get this problem fixed.  Liked to play the blame game

You could not review or rate upper management. Unprofessional upper managers.

Upper management did not care why supervisor turnover was so high. It appeared that they were not interested 

High supervisor turnover..within a year 1/3 of my colleagues changed. 

While in meetings not treated with respect.   Talked down to.  Threats of termination is were often while in group meeting.

pros:
- Employee lunches (free food occasionally)
- Company matches up to 5% towards your 401k
- Life is good if you are in management/supervisor position. You get to watch the grunts make the company millions.
- Management/Supervisors receive "company cards" and get to treat themselves and each other to breakfast, lunch, dinner, drinks, golf outtings, you name it. Must be nice.
cons:
- You are over worked and under paid.
- Supervisors/Management will receive annual bonuses in the thousands because you the worker worked harder, faster, and did not get hurt while doing so.
- Oh you busted your butt to get the work done sooner than expected? Here take this brush and go scrup the floor until its time to clock out.
- Verbal abuse
- Constantly being micromanaged
- You will receive a write up for EVERYTHING.
- If you enjoy working twice as hard as those above you and receiving half the pay, this is the place for you!
- Looking to move up? Good luck. 
- This company would rather hire someone who has never done the job to come be your boss rather than promote veteran employees.

pros: They have good benefits and every quarter, they have a production meeting. Offer good food, and raffles for some pretty good prizes. People get recognition.
cons:
Ah, where to start... They have the pay scale posted in the break room. They have new hire pay, 6 months, 12 months and 18 months. After Working by myself on second shift, I have a great review. I asked my supervisor if I would be getting a raise and was told, "I don't see why not". After waiting a few weeks, I was told "no, they want to see more." I asked what I need to do to receive a raise, again it was "more". They could not give me any detail. I asked what area I need to improve and again I was told that they want to see more. They did not say that anything was wrong, they just wanted to see if I would keep up with what I had been doing. Same thing happened on my 12 month review. When I asked why I wouldn't make more than starting pay for being there for 12 months, I was told that there were people there for 10 years still making starting pay! I asked them why they had the raises put on a calendar system and I was told that they had to put something down!
I left them with only a 2 day notice.
Do you self a favor and don't work there.

pros: I cant think of a single one. The pay isnt even that great now that you can go anywhere and make fifteen bucks an hour .. so .. they watch you pee now? Who doesnt like that?! And you get to pee twice because that's "always" been the policy and just noone knew .. right ..
cons:
I could go on all day .. not exaggerating. They're two faced, liars, back stabbers, thieves (better check your paychecks friends! More than likely theyve either taken money or extra psl hours .. or both). I honestly cant name a single good thing about the place. 
Even the few good supervisors there dont stand up for what's right when the rest of management are harassing and bullying someone so I just dont have any respect for then either. 
Still not exaggerating either. If one person decides they dont like you, you can be superman, the absolute best at ever job there that theyve ever seen, and it doesnt mean a damn thing. They (supervisors and higher management) will harass you and they will encourage the other supervisors to do the same. Theyll even go as far as lying about everything under the sun to get you or get people to help them get at you. Its sick.

pros: I work at the Carrollton,Texas Container plant. There are no pros about working for this location of IP. The management is complacent and the entire production process needs an overhaul, especially with the delaminated and warped paper that our customers complain about.
cons: This IP plant overlooks experienced employees and puts friends, family members and unqualified persons at top positions who lack experience and leadership skills. A current employee who only has three years experience was made leadman and more qualified and more experienced employees of over 15 years experience were ignored. These decisions bring lack motivation,resentment and production and our customers suffer for these bad decisions.

pros: Pay is very competitive and the job is very interesting if you like to be hands on. Many locations give any endless chance for advancement. Employee safety is the primary focus.
cons: Most local promotions are done from the outside. Advancement almost always requires a move to a different location. Also Management changes every 2-3 yrs and the rules change with them.

review_title: Decent company but very old fashioned
pros: Good ability to move around internally, especially as a new hire.  Fairly good pay, especially for Memphis.
cons:
Very old fashioned. I guess one shouldn't expect forward thinking from an old manufacturing company, but i t was very frustrating how behind the times IP was in many ways. Horrible maternity leave, the idea of paternity leave literally would generate a lol from management, they wouldn't even consider temporary flexible work arrangements.  IP is one of the last companies to still have a pension (closed for new hires).  This pension means the company skews VERY old as people will not leave.  The company is wildly out of touch with  under 40 crowd, much less the priorities of recent college grads.   In many ways its like 1985 at IP.   Almost every senior person you will interact with is a married old  white man. 

Cant speak for all groups, but communication was horrible in mine.  No one ever had any idea what the hell was going on.

review_title: Depending what shift are you starting you’ll be OK
pros: You can make a lot of money with them if you don’t mind giving up your life.They have a point system they use so if you have a emergency they tell you to use your points and if you run out of points you are a goner
cons: For the most part I was ok till they moved me with out asking me to a 3rd shift on the corrugater were I found the disrespectful people I have ever met when I asked for the disrespect to stop it turned violent when I reported it to HR with witnesses I only ended up getting myself fired they did not want to hear anything Me or my witness had to say

review_title: Big Pay difference between Union location & non-union
job_title: Machine Operator in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good benefits, although a little high on health insurance.  worked at both locations in San Antonio Tx & there is an unbelieveable difference in pay between the Union shop & the non-union location. Plus Union location gets a company paid retirement in addition to their 401-k!  Can't complain about that!  A lot of the workers make more than supervisors or Mgrs because of all the overtime worked. Good people make it a great place to work. Hands down SA Central location is better cuz of pay, benefits, people, etc.
cons: You should put in a change of address, because you're gonna spend most of your time there because of overtime! I worked at both locations & supervisors at both can be jerks.  Theres no loyalty on the companies part.  Long term employees leave  cause there offered better jobs, not as many hours

review_title: Not for the faint of heart...and prepare for chaos
pros:
Compensation is high and benefits are great.
Coworkers at your level are great and willing to help out when you need it.
Seems like a great company if you are single or willing to not see your family for what seem like days.
cons:
Compensation is low when you consistently work 60+ hour weeks including the weekend. Was not informed of this when interviewing.

Work life balance? Nope, most workers are senior in age and will lack empathy for younger workers. Turnover is high due to this, which leads to "No change" in group thinking.

Coworkers above you give little to no respect to those below as they think of their career first.

A lot of talk and no walk on culture change. IP is facing 30-50% retirement in 10 years but hasn't changed on the workplace culture.

1 year commitment for salaried hires, you will count the days until you can leave if you get a bad mill.

pros:
Moderately good pay for the position
Friendly coworkers
cons:
The way they do shift changes is awful. If you’ve been requesting a different shift for months, and some guy who has a week or month of seniority over you and just requests it the day before, he’s gonna get it, not you, because he has a bit more seniority over you.

Paying for union and using their benefits is mandatory

Attendance “point” system is awful for the first 90 days of probation. If you’re throwing up or even coughing up blood and need to call out for a few days, better start looking for a new job.

A lot of “don’t ask? Won’t tell” mentality. You’re almost expected to ask all different kinds of questions because no one will tell you if you don’t ask.

If you’re the new guy, you are literally the runt of your shift. If no one wants to do overtime, either you’ll have to do it or you’ll get a mark on your attendance.

pros: Seems to be stable company. Its a very big company. Pay meets the market.
cons:
You do as your told. Micro managed to death. There seems to be a lot of back stabbing. no one trust anybody. Nobody really seems to care or be invested in the operation. We just show up and do as we are told. Good or bad. if a problem or something bad happens the managers all go into a blame game.   
All the new managers seem like they don't want to be there or they just don't care. Our site is punishment duty for them it seems. Before you do anything you better have someone else set up that you can blame it it goes wrong. Your manager has you set up for their failures

review_title: Not a difficult job, great benefits, great starting pay.
pros: A great place to get your foot in the door and rise to better opportunities in the future. The pay is high, work is simple, union takes good care of its people. Best of all, there is a sense of trust that you get from your superiors; very comfortable atmosphere.
cons: Some mishandling of scheduling and logistics by management which causes rifts with hourly workers. Accountability is not always pointed to the appropriate party. Worst of all, the negativity by a majority of employees; at least half of the production workers are stuck in the past and refuse to think optimistically or progressively, creating a sour vibe that I would suggest new hires try to avoid. Make of it what you want, not what others tell you to.

pros: They have a really competitive pay especially if you are in Memphis where the cost of living is so low. Raises every year. Managers who want to see you grow with the company. Memphis is a great city for new grads and the campus is a nice place to work.
cons: Very old school. Not much vacation early on and you really have to earn your seat at the table. I think this is causing young talent to run fast. But if you sit and wait your turn it can pay off.

pros: International Paper has a strong rotation system for new hires out of college where they can move to different positions after 12-18 month rotations.  It is a very secure job to have in Memphis. IP offers the standard package of Corporate Benefits. There are many places to move if you so desire to test/expand your skills in other fields.
cons: The environment doesn't lend itself to having all employees feeling important. Though continuously ranked on Computer Worlds Best Places to Work in IT.  Leadership at IP tends to take an 'if it ain't broke don't fix it' stance to innovation and development. As a result the IT environment is dull. Company bonuses are only given to upper management so non-management employees have NO incentive to actually care about the company, its profits, or its stance in the industry. IP has no culture and only senior management is excited about the company (see above)

review_title: Average company, but can be difficult to develop your career
job_title: Applications Development Specialist II in Memphis, TN
pros: Competitive salary offer for entry level employees - Memphis is a city with a low cost of living, and the pay for IT positions is very good for entry level employees.  IP is one of the largest companies in Memphis allowing employees to take advantage of local discounts and promotions such as Grizzlies and Redbirds events.
cons:
Industry heavily influenced by economic trends
Highly focused on cost savings above all else

The company gives full control of your 'releaseable' status to your department manager.  This can effectively block any career development if you are filling a business need during a extended hiring freeze.  The company is currently engaging in 'cost savings through attrition'; many positions are not being back filled and duties are spread over existing employees.  In efforts to save money, tuition reimbursement, hardware refreshes, and BlackBerry service have all be discontinued indefinitely.

review_title: Good Company But:  No Accountability for Middle Managements Professionalism  eg: GM's
pros: Good pay &  benefits. Opportunities to advance. Corporate personnel great to work with.
cons: Remote plant's GM's have no sales experience are then expected to manage sales teams. I believe this to be a very weak area for the corporation.
