Also, non performing sales representatives are not held accountable for their time or lack of production. In my case may sales colleague continually cold called in my territory with communication, GM approved causing conflict. Lack of professionalism.

pros: A large company with many opportunities both in the US and around the world.  IP pays well, with benefits on par with the competition.  You can potentially move between functions in addition to transferring from one locale to another.  The atmosphere is, for the most part, informal and most managers are more than willing to share information and knowledge for the good of the organization.
cons: Many of the managers are unschooled in how to manage people; many are swayed by appearances rather than results in their promotion and treatment of subordinates.  Politics play a major role in advancement beyond middle management ranks.  It is often assumed that performance is directly related to hours spent at the office.

review_title: A company that strives to continually improve the manufactured products as well as the service they provide.
pros: The salary and benefit packages are competitive within their respective markets. As a leader in the pulp and paper market there are many operations throughout the US therefore affording opportunities for growth and advancement. Diversity within the company's senior leadership team all the way down to the production floor provides a culture that reflects the communities and customers they service.
cons: Information doesn't flow as smoothly as it should. Communication can be slow to filter down to those who carry out the orders. Changes in processes or procedures are not presented effectively at times. Often those responsible for implementing these changes arent sufficiently informed/trained on the new process and therefore unable to effectively train the employees who are affected by the change.

review_title: You do not need to know stats to do the job.
pros: Market Leader, strives for pest practices.  The company is environmentally focused and does care about employee well being and safety.  Each employee is required to take 4 safety credits during the year.  Topics range from plant safety to office safety to child car seat safety to home security.  They do care about your well being.
cons: Corporate policy can really suck at times.  If you are one a project that spans multiple divisions and one of those divisions is being sold off, you have to reapply for your job even if your time spent on that division was very minor.  Outsiders with no box plant or mill supply chain experience will have a tough time convencing older IP workers that they know something about supply chain.

pros: It seems to be a stable company
cons: I applied for a position and a month later received a call for an interview, after the interview I recived a call for 2nd interview and was told a decision would be made within 2-3 weeks ,I was told I was one of the 3 candidates for the final selection and I would be updated. I made an inquiry after a month becasue I had another interview lined up and was told that a decision still had not been made but that I would be notified one way or the other. I never got a call back to tell me one thing or the other. Out of courtesy to me taking the time to interview during odd hours of the day ,I should have been notified.

review_title: Successful company committed to safety, people development, and doing business with integrity.
job_title: IT Business Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros: Internal movement is encouraged and championed. The company has strong leadership and people development processes.  It is the market leader in most markets segments it competes in.  Good 401k plan.  Has proven success in declining markets and above market growth in growing markets.  Stock price has increased in the last 5 years.  Values clear expectations.  Easy-going about sick days and personal appointments during work hours.  International opportunities.
cons: Slow vacation growth.  Underperforming and non-core businesses seem always at risk of being sold.  Facilities are located in remote locations which can discourage internal movement.

pros:
Pay
Co-workers are awesome
Supervisors are top notch
cons:
Management above the supervisors  are terrible

Promotion process is a joke. They use the employee handbook “policies” when it fits their narrative for the month.

If you become complacent in a 12 hour shift and make a mistake you will be written up.

review_title: I have been very successful in this company.  I love my job and I am concerned why other individuals do not like theirs.
pros: International Paper allows all employees to receive medical benefits.  The company provides great health insurance that covers the whole family.  Promotions are guarenteed if you have been employeed long enough.  This company will not let anyone stay in a position for years.
cons: The only cons are having to work solo on projects and having to work with foreigners that have different methods of doing businesses.  That goes with international business though.  Learning to adapt and be willing to do things differently can be hard at times.

pros: You get your paycheck and if that's all you want then it's the company for you. If you can talk a good game chances are upper management will do no leg work to prove you can do what you say.
cons: Horrible management practices, doesn't value long term employees or their families. This company says safety is #1 but we all know it's about the money. They put safety practices in place that make it near in possible for you to perform then hold you accountable for it. Arm chair safety policies in place by people who can,t haven't, and won't ever understand what it takes to get a job done. It would be like having your child write an ergonomics program for someone who does desk work.

review_title: They treat workers fairly, but will do work.
pros:
-Mostly good treatment for workers (3 weeks vacation starting, good sick leave policy, good new parent leave policies)
-Good health insurance
-Small student loan repayment help
-Challenging projects
-You probably won’t get bored
-Strong emphasis on worker safety
cons:
-Older technology
-Lack of flex work options (WFH to be used sparingly)
-Can be very easy to be encouraged to do far more than 45 hours of work per week—can sometimes be 60-70 for weeks at a time 
-Culture leaves something to be desired—IP has a very old corporate culture. Very risk averse, mostly closed disruptive ideas despite innovation initiatives 
-Very behind the curve on technology

review_title: Opportunities exist but make sure you are in charge of your career planning from day one.
pros: A large company with opportunities to grow if you are willing to move often.  Salaries are good but you must know your value to the organization and be firm when it's time to negotiate your compensation.   IP has a great attitude pertaining to training and can be very supportive when an employee's training needs are identified.
cons: Large company that makes it difficult to figure out your place and the value of your potential within the organization.  Like most large companies, corporate politics can play a significant role in your career.  At times it seems like how you are perceived is as important as how you perform.  This "perception issue" can make or break your career.

review_title: A Great Company in A Shrinking Market
job_title: Program Manager, Color and Appearance in Hurricane, UT
pros:
International Paper is the largest paper company in the world; therefore they frequently lead and others follow them. They are not afraid of innovation. For example, I was tasked in 2005 with raising the brightness of commodity paper from 84 to 92 and CIE whiteness from 100 to 146. 

There is often room to grow in this company with its many paper mills and roles to support them.

P.S. I worked at IP until October 31, 2009.
cons: As a very large company, there is a lot of bureaucracy to weed ones way through. Sometimes it seems that reports are required just for the sake of having the reports themselves. They did not frequently seem to drive the business objectives of the company.

pros: Great place to work if you're willing to work hard you will have a great career there and moving up is easy as long as you put in the effort and care about you're work.
cons: They brought in new management at fox valley aurora and they were a disaster until the day I was let go, worked my but off for 5 years and left with nothing I felt.  Showed up 10 mins late to work my first time ever showing up late to work and machine was down and I was let go.. I had one point for missing a punch even thought I know I punched in.. My dad was in a car accident and I left 2 hours early on a Saturday and got a point.. Moral of what  all I'm saying it has great perks and great environment to work for, but you're managers and supervisors do not have you're back when times are tough.

job_title: Packaging Line Operator in Loveland, OH
pros: The best thing I like about working at IP is enjoying the Benefits of salaried employees.  Leadership is great and the company as a whole is one of most safety minded engaged facility that I have ever worked for.  IP Sumter Sheeting that is!  Not one complaint in the area of safety.
cons: 12 hr rotating shifts, while not all that bad tends effect your sleep habits.  I think we could stand another dollar or two, I think we are the lowest paid IP facility that exist.  That in-turn is good for company cost and expense's, but not for the employee or the moral withing a facility where everyone does they're best to see the company succeed.

review_title: Stable company but firmly entrenched in older mentalities and practices, too conservitive.
pros: They will do the best they can to retain their cooperate staff in these difficult economic times; as long as you have pulled your share. The paper industry is not going any where anytime soon and International Paper is very involved in conservation and sustainable practices. Company is very active in international expansion.
cons: Very conservative cooperate environment and overly traditional. The one progressive change they made was too drastic and incorrect; selling all of the land. They also terminated the pension program recently. Project management regularly incorrectly estimates, and is too accommodating to schedule slippage and budget overflows. Outsourcing is becoming a common practice.

pros: Outstanding Benefits, especially pay, dental, and vision. Health benefits are around normal. Outstanding support if you go out on sick leave. Really are a safety first culture that genuinely cares for their employees physical well being.
cons:
Expect long hours as a salary maintenance person. In fact, you will basically give a blank check for your time. It would be difficult to, say, plan a diner night out during the week, in advance. This is mainly due to the current poor condition of mill equipment. In fairness to IP, they are making considerable capital improvements to address the issue, however they aren't there yet.
Management culture can be on the hostile side, especially around unplanned equipment breakdown events.

review_title: Great company that has potential to be a great work environment
pros: Executive Leadership has a great vision and great values. Company has the potential to be a really fantastic work environment if they manage their talent pool effectively.
cons: Values and policies don't filter down to middle management (transparency, communication, and basic corporate policies). Need to start really looking at the impact of management. Middle management would benefit from more training in effectively managing and engaging their teams. Some managers are hired through networking but are not effective leaders.

pros:
*Great opportunities for advancement, not just at your own mill, but at other locations within the company. 
*IP does a great job training their engineers and management in problem solving techniques, leadership classes, technical training from experts, etc. 
*Pay is great. One of the highest paying employers in the locations I have been in. 
*I loves the transparency within the company. As a new engineer, I had several opportunities to interact with senior Vice Presidents and the CEO.
cons:
*Work/life balance is not good. Expected to work long hours with no comp time. 
*New engineers are expected to work as a shift manager within their first few years. Many are not interested in this, but it's pretty much forced in order to advance.

review_title: If you love a cubicle, this is the job for you
pros:
Pay and flexibility were good. Many of my coworkers could bring their kids to work. 
Covered parking with security and an onsite cafe and Starbucks
Remote access to work from home
cons:
Conflicting metrics across the company never let you feel like you do a good job
Poor training
Lots of turnover of millennials, company still using old practices, not very efficient. Alot of double work keeps you trapped at your desk or in endless meetings that fail to generate change withing the business group.

pros:
Decent pay (competitive)
Great benefits (besides health insurance)
Great people to work with
Advancement opportunities
Extra activities provided by company
Large company with opportunity to relocate
Fast paced environment
Very busy all the time and the time flies by
cons:
Very top down approach, everything has to go through your manager, which then goes to their manager etc. It is a lenghty process to get anything approved. I do not know if it is a power struggle or what. 
Everyone gets the same raise every year as long as you do your job.
Since it is such a large company sometimes you do not get the recognition you deserve. 
Hard to have a work life balance since it is such a stressful and demanding job.

pros: Environment, Safety Culture, Benefits, Salary, Training. I can't say enough about how  much I love working at IP. I have a flexible schedule and the ability to do my job without being micromanaged. Pay is right on the mark for the industry and the benefits can't be beat. 1 week vacation for the first year, then 3 weeks vacation after that. Floating holidays + awesome health insurance. IP is a class act and I feel very lucky to be a part of the team!
cons: They push you outside of your comfort zone to improve. Sometime the sales goals are pretty aggressive, but as long as you're giving it your all, you'll be fine!

review_title: The good and bad of working at IP
pros: The pay and benifits for working with IP is a definite positive.  With the exception of shiftworkers, flexibility of hours to fit your home life are is also a positive.  International Paper does well at family and community relations.  They go out of their way to do the right thing when it come taking care of employees and employee families.
cons: Most managers at IP do not seem to relate to hourly workers.  Communications from salaried to hourly workers, and hourly to salaried workers is poor at best.  Like most U.S. based companies, Inernational Paper is downsizing regularly.  The impact on employees and community are always going to be a "downside".

review_title: A good company in a tough business environment.
pros: The company offers competitive pay and benefits with strong emphasis on a safe work environment. There are many facility locations, leading to the possibility to live in an area where one wishes. Many employees have enjoyed a long stable work history with the company. The company has a diverse workforce with clear anti-discrimination policies.
cons: The company is undergoing downsizing of salaried positions. This appears likely to continue. Virtually all decisions are made from the top. There are strict bureaucratic procedures for all activities. Most facilities are located in remote areas resulting in long commutes for those who don't wish to live in the country. Unofficially, promotion requires relocation to facilities around the country/world.

review_title: IP is a good company, but is struggling right now as so many are.
pros: There is fairly open communication from management about the company's direction. Employees are given feedback regularly about their performance. The company tries more than most to make employees feel appreciated.
cons: The challenges presented by a dwindling stock price lead to unpopular management decisions. At times these decisions can seem heartless. One example would be the decision to close a profitable plant when changing the focus of the company. Instead of selling the plant to a competitor, the plant was closed and the hard-working employees who had been making profits for the company were left without jobs.

review_title: Above average pay with a good benifits package. For the industry it's a good place to work.
pros: Benefits are above average and a wide variety of health plans are offered. Long Term Disability, Life Insurance and a good matching 401K is offered.
cons: Just another warehousing logistics job. Managers are sub par along with mist of the labor field. Everyone seems to carry a chip on their soldiers and not thankful for what they have. At 20 bucks and hour for driving a truck and 18 for working in a warehouse the workers need to perform much better. Moving up in IP can be difficult unless you have a job which allows you to converse with many people.

review_title: I'm a maintenance mechanic, been here 14 years and I still love this job!
pros: Great money!, hourly, overtime and profit sharing. NEVER hassled about time off EVER! Lots of additional trade training. My opinion and experience counts. They have an excellent safety program and they take safety very seriously. Everyone is equal, you can talk to anyone from supervisors and area managers all the way up to the mill manager anytime about anything. I like the atmosphere, it's laid back when things are going good and serious and challenging when they aren't.
cons: Typical stuff like lack of communication, why don't they fix this or that, nothing to lose sleep over. I can't think of anything that would make me want to seek another job.

pros: Great benefits, especially the 401k matching and healthcare options.  Excellent career path development.  Good coworkers who genuinely care about each other and doing a good job.  Compensation is very competitive. Strong commitment to the environment and sustainability.  The opportunity to follow your career path to other locations (some even international!).
cons: The union leadership in the manufacturing facilities can be challenging to work with at times, however some of the union guys have been the best guys to work with in terms of knowledge and commitment.

review_title: Good Company with a great work environment
pros: Management is fair with workload. Pay is good for first job in the field.  Have a great network linking  you with other new hires, interns and as many people as possible.  Overall great environment to work in.
cons: First couple steps up the ladder seem more about putting your time in than actively excelling.  Some people tend to work less hours frequently and not receive any punishment. Teams tend to not immediately include you so you occasionally have to find your own work

review_title: I've loved working here, but know some folks who have had a bad expierece.
pros: Travel opportunities.  Many locations all over the US and abroad to work at.  Job Security even in a rough economy for most places.   Good pay for salaried folks, not sure about hourly?  Wide variety of jobs, from manufacturing to sales to sitting in a cube
cons:
Too many bosses, to few workers in mos cases.  If you get attached to a speciic location, there is alwasy a chance it could get shutdown.  Have to try and maintain some ties with the corporate office.
Sometimes the stupidest people dont get fired, they just get moved around to another departments.

review_title: Good for robots, Not so much if you want a future.
job_title: Operator's Assistant in White Bear Lake, Ramsey, Optional[MN]
pros: Good if you need a job, and don't mind management making it up as they go along, at your expense.
cons:
Where to start? I guess we will start at the top and work our way down. The plant general manager, walks around calling employees "peter buffers" the things that come out of his mouth are repulsive and offensive. How he has not been sued yet is beyond me. 

The atmosphere consists of bend over at the drop of a hat. we will sacrifice every last one of you to move product and protect are bonus.

job_title: Machine Operator in Carol Stream, IL
pros: Very easy job. If you like to keep busy and make some good money and overtime. This is your place.  Learned a lot from this place. Good people. Hardworking.
cons:
Overtime is mandatory. So if you bail out on a day that requires you to come in early or on a Saturday, it will effect your attendance. Meaning you will be let go just for that. No matter what excuse.  
Hours are long and this job will wear you out pretty good.  You will be busy and your free time will be limited. So if you have kids. Plan carefully. 12 hour shifts are very common with this place.

review_title: Some Mills Much Better Than Others
pros: Tex mill has a good market for the products it makes.  Occasional market driven downtime but good solid future.
cons: The Tex mill was built on the cheap and suffers from it.  You can make butter with a toothpick, but its damn hard.  Review system dictates lots of low performers even when you look at what they do and are impressed at what they do.  So messed up.  Raises are good for younger engineers, not so much for more experienced.

pros: Great people, good pay, opportunity for development if willing to relocate; all the benefits of working for a major corporation
cons: Senior Management is isolated from the day to day; need to listen to the employees more, program for promoting people is not always effective; highly competitive across business segments; stressful with long hours/weeks

pros: I cannot think of anything good, pay and benefits suck for what you give up no work life balance, work atmosphere is next level hell
cons: seven days a week 8 to 12 hours per day mandatory, not knowing if you will have to come in early or stay late to cover someone shift, all equipment run down broke or rigged to run, no PM in years, completely a reactive approach to maintenance, have to call in sick on a Sundays for kids and grand kids birthdays,  point system, management sucks, two faced coworkers, lie to you about what needs finished or do not report downed equipment or calls so they can leave go home, no tools - tools ordered are put on hold and they expect you to work on the broken equipment with worn out tools,

pros: Great benefits, really rewards their employees financially
cons: Work life balance is terrible. Management is completely out of touch with reality. The culture is just that... very cultish. There is nothing down to earth regarding the people who make decisions in the facility. To the ones who are delusional regarding their abilities/policies, just be confident in your delusion and you will go very far. Speaking the truth and being honest in this facility is extremely discouraged in the most passive aggressive manner possible. If you are an expert in corporate double-speak, then this is the place for you.

review_title: Your experience is very dependent on your manager
pros:
I enjoyed my first position with IP, good pay and low stress and a great boss. However I had issues when I moved out of Memphis for a new position. I had a difficult position but I believe it would have been easier and less stressful if I had support from my manager. I ended up leaving because I felt the 
"ok" salary wasn't worth the stress and disrespect from my manager.
cons: Allows poor performers, bullies, and non-cooperative people stay in the company. Company loyalty wins out over performance.

review_title: Learned a lot in art department.
pros: Understanding manager, great art and customer service team, Tuition reimbursement, 401k, 15 days pto, a few sick days, no weekends, paid over time,  wellness program that helps save a LOT on health insurance, and the pay is good.
cons: For me with an hour drive and young kids work/ life balance is NOT GOOD. Last minute orders needed the next day are a constant and communication between the smaller  art department and the larger sister art department is an area of tension and in need of much improvement. An additional member of the smaller team making it 6 instead of 5 would help greatly. Easy fix that I'm sure will be applied in the future.

review_title: Great Place to work in Memphis
pros: Well known and respected employer in Memphis. Great culture overall.  Professional and friendly environment. Great leadership and career development program. Varies team to team, but in supply chain you have a lot of flexibility and work/ life balance. In general, most employees are quite happy and motivated. Standard benefits, no bonuses in supply chain.
cons: It is definitely a corporate environment. This means, lots of meetings, lots of red tape, slow to react to market or implement change. Some bureaucracy and politics.

pros: Many. I left a union job to work there. They were safer than the union job, had better benefits and paid a lot better for easier tasks. Also more and better advancement opportunities. Lots of chances to work OT. I wish they hadn't sold us to another company.
cons: In my case a very long drive made the 12 hours shifts very hard. The insurance companies were't real great, especially the one that handled medical leave and stuff like that. Sometimes too much OT.  Now the plant is sold to another company that isn't as concerned with safety.

review_title: International Papers treated me with respect upon my leaving the company due to a downsizing of workforce.
pros: Since leaving the employment of the IP, I keep in touch through the Quarter Century Club, miscellaneous doings provided by the mill, monthly mill update newsletter, and just simply going back to the mill for a visit.  I have been treated with respect there at the mill since by all.
cons: The only "con" I have at this time is the fact that I lost the direct communication between myself, my fellow workers, and management.

review_title: Solid company, solid people, reasonable expectations
job_title: SAP BW Developer in Memphis, TN
pros: (For the IT org): Really solid training opportunities, good onboarding, good company culture, truly decent and basically good colleagues.  The comp, benefits, vacation, etc., are fairly standard.  Start before New Years, and you'll pick up nearly a full year toward your vacation increase at 5 years (effectively waiting only 4 years to get that extra week off).  IP is a steady and predictable employer, and managers generally do their best to ensure a happy, healthy workforce.  If you're willing to go out on the limb, branch out and learn a new position, you will usually be encouraged.  They're big enough to absorb your vacancy, meaning you're usually 'releasable' to another manager for internal moves, and standouts are recognized.  Shared Services model in IT allows if not encourages cross-pollination and syntopical learning.  You can be silo'd if you choose to be, or you can float positions every couple of years if you like.  It is unlikely that a solid worker would be downsized, as efforts are made to retain 'people', not just positions.  I had an excellent experience at IP, and would return w/o hesitation if the circumstances making that feasible arose.
cons:
If you really dig in and stick to a particular specialty, then advancement can be slow.  In big, stable companies, many other employees realize when they have it good as well, so without standout performance or a few lateral moves (to round out technical and business experience), advancement might take a while.
IF an individual thrives in a churning environment, then a smaller company with less process and planning might be preferred.  The truly restless acheiver might feel stagnate, but again, a change of position and new learning is one way to keep things interesting w/o changing companies.  IP is big enough to sustain some employee drift within the organization.  If I had it to do over, I would have 'drifted' through more roles.

review_title: Probably great environment for aged workers, not necessarily millenials
pros: If you want a place to play it safe with your career, then you've found your match.  It's not necessarily an exciting industry but at least you know the company is stable, the pay is decent (not to be confused with fair), you'll get a full range of benefits (not the best, but not the worst either), tuition reimbursement, processes are centralized and automated, and career, learning, leadership training, and travel opportunities exist.  If you work at corporate, there are even greater perks such as drawings for attending arena events like NBA games and major concerts or getting classroom projects sent to your child's school like watching butterflies grow or magazine subscriptions.
cons:
I felt like the company bullied Memphis when it threatened to leave the city unless it extended a tax benefit it had been receiving for 20 years. As someone who remembers attending school without air conditioning, that tax revenue from this multi-billion dollar company was greatly missed by the city's school system, yet the company will like to tout its $1-2M charitable donations per year to local organizations.  

After getting it's way and expanding it's HQ, you would think maybe an onsite daycare or pumping rooms would have been included as part of the plan with what more modern-engaged companies are doing, but maybe that's a symptom of the leadership being mainly baby-boomers.  

Also, a lot of the field locations are in the boondocks. So for younger employees, the prospect of spending three or more years of your best years in a place that lacks basic recreation or the potential for finding a partner becomes bleak no matter how much they pay you.  

If you aren't careful, you will notice that IP will slowly, but surely become your life. Meanwhile, piece by piece you will have given up the parts of your life that made you who you are.  It's a lot of people there that have spent their entire careers at the company so it's all they know.  As a result, if you have an existing, continual commitment in your life that conflicts with work arrangements, these types of employee feel like you just need to give up what it is you've always done before you got there because IP is all that matters and there should be not flexibility on its part. 

At IP, you get sold the mantra of infinite possibilities regarding career opportunities.  However, what they don't tell you is that at the end of the day, they will place you where they want you to go when they want you to go there.  So that means even if there's an opportunity available for which you qualify, you may not get it because your manager considers you to be non-releasable.  There also isn't a whole lot of credence given to your experience gained outside of the company.  It's almost as if what you had done before doesn't matter because they didn't see you do it there.

review_title: Under recognized company, great place to work.
pros: Strong company, good people, good plan for future success.  Of course the paper business isn't the most exciting field in the world, but International Paper is very focused on technology to get ahead of the competition.  Of all paper companies, IP is certainly the most advanced.
cons: Not a technology company.  Not a lot of room for growth in IT unless you are willing to relocate.  IT is sometimes seen as a necessary evil, mostly from small people on the inside, like local controllers and plant managers.  People at the site level have not yet recognized how to use technology to it's advantage.

pros: Great opportunity to become a versatile asset to IP and any other organization in your future endeavors. Ample training that can be tailored to your career path. Lots of opportunity for growth within the company.
cons: Requires multiple/random late nights and weekend duty. Although the company as a whole is top-tier, the Bogalusa location has some major holes when it comes racial inequality (just look at the turn over rate for minorities in salary positions). This is done by keeping 1 or 2 minorities engaged and screwing the rest, may be due to the culture of the city and mill (google it).

review_title: Bittersweet Experience. Management Could Use Revamping
pros: Great perks such as giveaways. Staff is really nice and works well as a team. Will go above and beyond to do a good job and take care of the customer.
cons: Management can be disconnected with daily activities of employees and processes. Systems are not efficient making it difficult to perform duties timely. Very bureaucratic, tough to be heard by management. Promotions and compensation aren't always fair. HR not approachable.

job_title: SAP Basis Administrator in Memphis, TN
pros: Invests in Information Technology internally with data center and employees in a time where out sourcing and hosting is thriving.
cons: Salary and merit increases are low but the cost of living in Memphis is also low justifying there reasoning.  The economy is still recovering at this time so merit raises can get better. Equipment is old and CRT rather than LCD are still used.  No head sets and shabby offices for the IT people.

review_title: If you're an outsider forget career advancement
pros: Pay and benefits, multiple career path options (by management choice), solid financial stability.
cons:
Redundant meetings with no results, slow decision making process. 

Engagement is lackluster, middle and upper level management do not engage employees. Managers are to worried about their next "opportunity" in making decisions, versus what's best for the future of the company.

If your hired in from the outside it's very hard to progress in this organization.

review_title: International Paper is a good company to work for
pros:
Safety Driven - they genuinely care about employee safety and will change processes to ensure it.
Union friendly - organized collective bargaining agreements are not a sin.
Opportunity for advancement - you move as far as you want. Work hard!
Fair salary and benefits which are competitive with industry.
Work-Life balance is pretty good.
cons:
Risk averse - very difficult to procure capital for improvements, especially if you are in a static or declining market sector. Prefers stability and the status quo as opposed to being first to market or a maverick.
Large bureaucracy - paper mills like to generate paperwork.
Medical benefits suffer weak packages along with most American businesses.

pros: pays well for a factory, co workers are great . insurance is so so. close to home for me . i myself enjoy working in a printing enviroment.
cons: managment team is very contridictive and confusing . they say safety above all else but hurry up. that makes no sense to me. they never follow their own rules and they  change rules to suit their own agenda.

pros: Contributions to school loans though I never saw the payments applied by the government.
cons: Discrimination, minimalization, mismanagement of resources, devaluation as a human if not on lead team, group think, people allowed to pretend to shoot you in hallway after saying " now you have a target on your head" and HR said, " what do you want me to do about it?"

review_title: Nice place to work if you like working!
job_title: Assistant Machine Operator in Salinas, CA
pros:
Lots of overtime available if you are up for it. They'll work you, thats for sure...

 Benefits are good, but seems you got to pay for lot of the insurance now. Not sure if the student loan repayment plan works for us on the "floor", but Im trying to utilize that currently ($9,000 lifetime contribution).

Decent pay for the requirements they want met. Where else can you get into a high paying job with a High School diploma? (I have a degree and other things, but still work here over a office cubical job...)

Best union I've been in by far. Ok work environment.
cons:
Company goes by seniority, so you may get forced to do lots of overtime. Vacation and other perks go to those with more seniority. Beginning out you usually are at the Cascaders/Waxers.  Out of the mid sized groups they hire at times only a few hard working people last. 

Its a dangerous job in some respects, watch where you stick your hands!

Jan-Feb are slow months with less work. 

You get stories from the old timers of what they used to offer and it seems we get less these days...For example; Im not sure the pay increases are beating inflation...

review_title: Not the best place to work
pros:
Union
Pay is okay not great
cons:
Management is poor
Moral is lacking
Extremely high turnover rate
Short breaks
Either very hot or cold in the plant depending on weather
Six day work weeks
Short notice on working weekends (sometimes 7 day work weeks)
Everything is broken and they don’t fix it
Nasty inside (ink, dust, glue & trash everywhere)
Vacation is a joke, takes takes 8 years to only get three weeks & 3 years to get two weeks
Point system is very hard to go down so it racks up fast
Management doesn’t know anything about fixing or running the machines

review_title: Great company, needs more diversity at mid-, and senior executive levels
pros: IP has numerous opportunities if you are willing to move and can adapt to living in smaller, rural locations. The Memphis headquarters provides a broad range of jobs and young professionals with drive will typically excel and be recognized. Compensation is above average for the industry.
cons: Bureaucracy is still an issue, though it improved over the time I worked there. Career paths are relatively specific and those who do not get experience in manufacturing, may find it hard to advance to senior levels.

pros: Overtime if you like working a lot.
cons:
The baler job is repetitive  and hard on your back and shoulders.  Management takes short cuts with lesser quality of paper used to produce bags which frequently break in the machines pushing back production then forcing people to work overtime during the week and work on Saturdays. 

Buena Park facility is small and no room for advancement from the baler job. There is no internal transfer opportunities from one facility to another. If you see a job you are interested in at another location you have to apply for it in the same manner as a non-employee. Also some locations are union and some aren't.

review_title: My time at International Paper was bittersweet. I worked with some very talented people, but was overqualified.
pros:
They take care of and care about their employees. They work with you if you are having personal issues.
For the most part they listen to their employees concerns and ideas. 
Their pay is above avg. for the position regionally and nationally.
cons:
There is a lot of red tape to get anything accomplished.
They are not narrow minded but they have the tendency to get tunnel vision and refuse to cut losses when better options are presented. Especially in IT. 
Starting off entry level IT there are very few options for advancement.

pros: Extremely competitive pay for the industry. Decent amount of upward mobility near term, endless amount if you're in for the long haul. The vast majority of management positions, entry level through senior, are held by employees within 10 years of retirement. Promotes from within. Very few management positions filled via external recruiting.
cons: Promotions are not always performance based. Who you know overrides what you know. Very traditional "old school" company with an aged workforce. Slowly becoming more progressive but still a decade behind companies of comparable size/revenue. Locations in every state in the US but all senior management positions located in Memphis.

pros:
IP calls its Technical Support Staff ITCS.  I worked for the manufacturing division which is very laid back.  We had some general flex time as long as staff was in the office from 7-6. This meant that some of us came in from 6-3 and others 9-6.  it was very nice and no questions were ever asked provided you were productive.  The company is very respectful and open minded to solutions I had many opportunities to utilize my specialize to create innovative solutions that were out of the box for IP at the time.  It isn't the most bleeding edge work in the world, but I found my time there very relaxing unless a critical problem arose and I was always given plenty of compensation for over-time

This is a great company to work for long term. Lots of movement potential and ability to work all over the world if you move towards management and financials.
cons:
IP is a very large very old company.  I can't complain enough about the entrenchment that goes on in management.  The problem with ITCS is that they are a cost center for the manufacturing decision they work and even though they pretend to have a chain of command I can't count the times a Division manager went around 3 levels of management to talk directly to me about a problem. 

I was always very uncomfortable in this situation, not because I couldn't handle the pressure from engineering, but because I would regularly get told by my own bosses not to directly speak to these individuals.  I found the management on my side to over react to small complication instead of seeking advise from those actually aware of the circumstance.

As a large corp you will be subjected to what ever management buzz course is being forced on your team for the year.  Be prepared to enter the world of office space when dealing with them directly.  This may be worse now that ITCS has moved across the street from Corp HQ.

review_title: Alot to work on but overall not a bad company
pros:
Always room for overtime opportunities.
Millwide and departmental training.
Safety is the number #1 key for IP as a whole.
Advancement  opportunities are given to those who are focus, dedicated, and pursuing careers.
cons:
Long hours based upon department not being fully staffed. 
Veterans afraid of change
Tier pay differences 
Work/Life balance 
High turnover rate based upon pay differences

review_title: Been a great place to work (Corporate-IT Staff)
pros:
Compensation has been very good overall. In my experience here, you get out of International Paper what you put into it. There are negative people here who complain about never getting ahead and such - but in most of those cases, they are overall very negative people and I think that will hamper you here at IP. A positive, ethical mindset and a good work ethic have allowed me to really grow at IP. The opportunity is here for those that are willing to dedicate themselves to the goal. 

At the same time, IP is *excellent* with their work/life balance. None of the other companies I have worked for even come close to IP's concern with your work/life balance. This is one of the things that really goes a LONG way to keeping me at IP.

They also actually send us to training. All companies promise to send IT to training - but in my experience, very few actually make good on this promise. IP has made good on this promise.

Very laid back environment
Excellent Management
Good compensation
Mostly good benefits
Outstanding corporate ethics and morals.
cons:
Large company - easy to get 'lost' in . This can sometimes lead to various team members taking advantage of the situation and not pulling their weight. While this does allow the more ambitious to succeed, it can also be annoying to some of the co-workers at IP.

IT staff is too tightly 'siloed' sometimes. While this does help with focused subject matter expertise, it can also lead to some tension between teams and a lack of understand of the job of peer employees.

At remote sites, career growth is not even possible to a large degree for 'corporate' employees. This is only a minor-con, depending on a person's situation. For those who do wish to move ahead with IP, they are certainly opportunities for those willing to relocate to the HQ in Memphis, TN

review_title: Competitive Salary & Benefits.  Limited advancement, obvious bias, high politics
job_title: Senior Sourcing Manager in Memphis, TN
pros: Competitive Salary - Benefits of holidays and vacation. 401K & retiree benefits. High performing colleagues.
cons: No advancement in 10+ years. Constant fear of layoffs and pay cuts. Hiring & Promotion Bias, highly political. Expensive Benefits. Mature Product and Industry - very risk averse, lacking in creativity, but top notch processes.

pros: Good People and sometimes a good work environment
cons: micro-management, "good old boy" mentality, no rhyme or reason why people get promoted to Senior or Director levels. It is all about who you know. People with no skills often promoted.

review_title: Decent company but upward mobility depends heavily on your manager and area
job_title: SAP Business Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: Decent benefits, flexible hours, generally motivated coworkers who care about customer needs
cons: Project managers and others want quick turnaround on implementations but blame you later when sustainable process had no time to develop under their deadlines.  Highly political culture with obvious back-scratching and favoritism.  Management speaks of "infinite" career possibilities but if your direct manager has no pull or drive, you're not going anywhere.

pros: Good benefits: Health, dental, EAP.  Salaries are higher than the national average.  I liked that fact that IP does give back to the community.
cons: Little sharing of information by management which results in a lack of clear direction as to what is expected.  Limited resources to meet goals assigned.

job_title: Machine Operator in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: good pay most employees were good to work with
cons: Management rushed training thru because they didn't have an operator then wondered why their numbers were down?? wonder why? supervisors are not connected to employees and only want numbers. Union, has its good and bad, the bad is they have an employee who is protected by the union they need to get rid of, even the union members no this employee does not get along with others. Lots of overtime when your a new employee sometimes its not necessary but supervisors like testing new employees.

review_title: large multinational with steady work and good leaders
pros:
Through the recent recession, employees were still given raises and cost of living wage increases. The company has recently refocused attention on core highly profitable long term businesses - making boxes for example and has become a world leader in this market and others. 
The company has been around for a long time (over 100 years) and is likely to be around for a lot longer. If you are interested in a large multinational with slow and steady growth, this is it. 

Mr. Faraci is in touch with his Memphis employees and is leading the company in the right direction. He took a very bold step in raising cash and taking on substantial debt to purchase a division from Weyerhaeuser but I believe that it was the right decision for the company.
cons:
This is low profit margin manufacturing large multinational company. 
Therefore there are many layers of management, too many useless and duplicate reports to do and other seemingless foolish administrative tasks that are not apparently useful to those working in the trenches. 
For similar reasons the company wants to justify every project and watches it's money very closely. 
Changes have to regarded 
Mid level managers may be under utilized and therefore have time to micromanage. Some employees, due to the size of the company, and a somewhat lax management attitude in some areas, feel that they can get away with not working. They may in the short term but International Paper will terminate them eventually (may take years) .  
Corporate at time's seems to kowtow to businesses units and manufacturing facilities, taking the attitude that if they say they have to have then they must be .
Too many "diverse" employee's in positions that they are unqualified and unsuited for. 
In some areas I have witness'ed a cliques led by managers lead to incometence being ignored.
Many employees know "the system " is broken and dont try to attempt to fix it any more and instead just allow it continue by lying about others performance or by finding another way to accomplish a task.
Thus failures are glossed over and allowed to continue. 

The company continues to pay lip service to environmental causes and in some cases is hypocritical.
For example the company will say one thing, and do another : it has an impressive media campaign that printing on paper is better than emailing yet internally has diverted all paper notices to email versions. 
Large office buildings within Memphis, could and should have been made green decades ago (solar panels) , an investment that would have paid for itself already. 
Company does not internally recycle cans, glass or plastic . Nor does it lead such recycling programs within the community.  
The company has reduced it's north american land holdings, avoiding the responsibility of land stewardship while at the same time promoting such stewardship.

The company continues to off shore as much work as possible. The US staff continue to drive the work but understand less and less as they have a hands off attitude and become more and more project managers. This results in systems which no one understands 2 years after building, and which often do not work. 

Corporate divisions such as Human Resources and IT are understaffed and have insufficient resources, leading to long lag times or no response.

review_title: This is a very good place to work.
pros: This company really cares about safety. They have good benefits and base salary at plants by local market. Some plants are union, but non-union plants usually get offered same negotiated benefits.
cons: Plant attendance policies vary by plant, so there are no set company wide policies regarding attendance and discipline, which can lead to peer review issues.

pros: Good pay and plenty of challenges to tackle. Company culture will completely back safety concerns and provide adequate capital for issues
cons: Lots of hours and usually complexed or regional for safety spreading things thin. Work life balance is not good, too many tasks for one person to complete or delegate properly without higher authority than position allows.

review_title: "Old" Company in More Ways Than One
job_title: Process Improvement Manager in Morristown, TN
pros:
Good retirement package.
Lots of corporate emphasis on safety.
Lots of locations if you want to move around within the company.
cons:
Company is an old company in an old industry and hasn't had to change much over the years. 
Entrenched unions in most locations - some locations with better relationships and some locations horrid. 
Leadership near the top of the organization (like EHS leadership) are way overkill on micromanaging lower-level leaders. Ability of lower leaders to tailor processes to their facilities so they actually work is stifled. 
So much paperwork and redundant effort to meet corporate requirements that it's hard to actually meet the spoken expectation of being on the floor with your people. Real expectations vs imaginary expectations.
Work/life balance is horrid in many locations. Salaried employees get paid based on 49hr work weeks, but are often expected to work 6-7 days a week in practice - averaging 60-80hrs in many positions. Often-times hourly work the same, but even overtime pay comes at a cost to their personal lives - voluntary or not.
The older-in-age management often have antiquated expectations of work-ethic where your work is your #1 loyalty and you will come in in the middle of the night and every weekend if we tell you to. This has had a widespread effect on company-wide culture. This will not work with younger generations in future decades - company needs to adapt to the times if they want to be successful.

pros: practice diversity in hiring key positions, promote safety and a healthy work environment, ability to have upward mobility, good interaction between departments, health benefits, good 401K program
cons: asked to do more with less (less support personnel, less tools to work with), too many projects and not enough internal support to see them fully develop

review_title: It is an okay place for stress free work
job_title: IT Business Consultant I in Memphis, TN
pros: Less stress for average sklled person. Benefits are good for the region and industry. Good place for beginners to build job skills.
cons: Growth opportunity is only based on communication skills and political savvy people. Technically skilled people in IT are not reviewed based on performance. Even if you save tons of money on projects, there is no payback to the contributor. There are plenty of managers ready to take credit for the work.

pros: Pay is very competitive overall. While I might be able to make more 'cash' at some other places, it wouldn't make up for the stability that IP has offered me, along with the total benefits package. Their Retirement plans are good, health benefits are decent, and there are many other benefits outside of these realms. I have actually gotten training, whereas many companies will promise training - IP delivered. There are a lot of good people to work with as well, I have had no major issues with management and even the 'high level' mangers are approachable, for the most part. From my experience, upper management is as in touch with their employees as they can be in an organization of this size. Outside of entire facility closure, I haven't seen any layoffs and even in those cases, the chances of being able to relocate (if willing) and maintain a position with IP have been good to excellent. In most areas there is little outsourcing and much of that is 'temp to hire' - and they actually do hire in many of those cases, if you do a good job. Additionally; while there is some debate overall on the subject, for the most part - hard work is rewarded. Very good life/work balance - when I needed time off the most, it wasn't even questioned - a manager 3 levels above me told me to take the time I need for my family.
cons: Large environment creates many 'work silos' - keeping you in a narrow scope of responsibilities, that can be a 'con' to a degree since you do not get much experience outside of your 'specialty'. It is also easy to get 'lost in the crowd' if you aren't a very assertive personality. Change is slow in coming and there can often be a 'hurry up and wait' dynamic on projects. Promotions can be limited, depending on the facility you are located at. the overly ambitious may not find it the best environment for quick advancement.

review_title: My experience has had many ups and downs.  Mostly ups.  My main dissatisfaction lies with advancement opportunities.
pros: The best reason to work for International Paper is the compensation. IP pays a living wage that allows its employees to make a comfortable living.
cons: The major downside to working at International Paper is the lack of career paths and advancement opportunities. Specifically, the policy that allows managers to prevent employees from applying for internal positions without their permission.

pros: Very friendly people, lots of personal development opportunities, emphasis on managers caring for their employees.
cons: Certain "favorite" people get promoted when much more qualified people are more deserving. It is like they must meet a quota of certain age, sex, race, etc., instead of promotions based on merit.

pros:
Started innovation which is slowly making headway.
Started Diversity and Inclusion - 
Good Pay for the job
cons:
Bad benefits
Company cares more about Core employees than long term employees
Promotions to senior level - not going to happen. The only way this will happen is if you are on a managed move list or have a mentor in director or above level (or you are Core).
Promotion into senior manager roles is not based on experience and performance.

review_title: Great company in a unique industry
pros: IP is a fantastic company to work for. There's plenty of opportunity to succeed if you're willing to put forth the effort. Those who do good work are often recognized with opportunities for advancement. The pay is on par with the industry and high for those living in Memphis, which has an incredibly low cost of living.
cons: Office politics can get in the way at the corporate office, but that can be said for any large corporation. Decision making can be a challenge, which causes unnecessary and frustrating delays in some circumstances.

pros: Great place to work. I learned a lot of good skills in operation of DCS and related equipment. I worked in the Power house and was treated much better there than I was in the Converting area.
cons: When International Paper is done with a Plant they shut it down, just like they did my plant, and all the rest. It doesn't mater if the plant is productive or not. Don't waste your time at a paper plant, paper is on its way out, you will just be looking for a job when you are older, it was nice while it lasted but it didn't last long   enough.

job_title: EHS Safety Manager in Columbia, SC
pros:
IP is a large corporation so there are almost limitless resources available if you know where and how to ask. The IP pay scale is commensurate with other similar companies. 
There are some great people working at IP.
cons:
Though the pay scale is commensurate with other companies, getting a promotion is usually very difficult. Like a lot of large companies where employees make good salaries, there is a lot of jealousy and envy amongst the employees about what each other is making. Who tells them? Instead of looking for very talented help and rewarding them for a job well done, they reward mediocrity with their sliding, bell curve based salary determination scale. If an employee has been doing excellent work for numerous years, they may get an increase in salary of up to 5%. (though it is usually between 0 & 1%, like .47% for example.) 
On the other hand, if an employee has been borderline at performing their job for most of their career, and they suddenly do their job, they get rewarded with the maximum 5% increase in salary! Where is the incentive for the high performers to keep producing? It's the proverbial story of the horse pulling the cart and the one tied to the back of the cart. The horse pulling the cart gets whipped if they suddenly let up, but the one following behind the cart doing nothing to help pull the cart, just keeps getting fed, watered and groomed!

job_title: Senior Transportation Planning Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros: Compettive pay is about all I can say about IP but only paid once a month which sucks!
cons: Terrible place for African Americans to work and try to advance. Very good ole boy environment and political to limiting your future. "Infinite possibilities" is  blatant lie!

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Morgantown, WV
pros: Family oriented company with long-tenured senior leaders who willingly interact and want to mentor new talent. Develop talent within and there are unlimited opportunities if you are willing to work hard and communicate openly with your manager.
cons: It depends on the business division in which you are placed, but a good amount of travel is usually involved since HR is very lean. This allows for a greater scope and experiences, but can be tiring.

pros: They are very big on people development, and have a lot of training opportunites for leadership and development.  It is a good team environment. There are so many opportunities around the United States, so if you are mobile, there are unlimited opportunites on positions.
cons: Some positions could be long hours during the month... especially finance around month-end

pros: Excellent starting pay.  Lots of overtime. Good benefits package from Teamster Union.  All Federal Holidays off with pay.  Friendly people
cons: Union shop so vacations and upward mobility is by seniority.  Floating holidays blacked out May through September.  Very hot working environment in summer.  Draconian attendance policy has been relieved somewhat by mandatory payed sick leave law

There are many mandatory meetings you have to attend in spite of the workload you might have, further pushing your paperwork behind. The benefits are not as good as other companies, only 3 days sick leave per year, $3,000 medical deductible.  Your family has to understand your work comes first.

review_title: It has been great working here.
pros: international gives alot of training on pumps,turbines,hydr.,deffern in types of oil,belt classes,bearing classes and more have learned a lot here and got alot of exspe.

pros: Decent Salary and Decent benefits

review_title: International Paper is a great Company to be part of

cons: Bad management.  No work/life balance, it's a lie.  Company on its last leg. Bad management decisions such as not wanting to fix machines, then they break, and they end up taking holidays away from employees, making them work. Bad environment. Will tell you plant is making $ but it's a lie.  Only has a few months to turn around or it will be shut down.  New management is bullying and harassing.  Doesn't care about employees, only about his results.

review_title: One of best companies to work for in Memphis, TN
pros: Opportunities for career development and advancement and above market salaries. Great opportunities for employees serious about their careers and the success of the company.
cons: Company headquartered in Memphis - not an ideal place to live for some and difficult for company to recruit talent from outside Memphis area. This can be a pro for good talent to negotiate better compensation packages.

review_title: Great company but some plants have culture issues with some managers lacking the knowledge and ability to improve.
pros: Overall mission and values conveyed by corporate are great!  Great benefits and corporate training initiatives.
cons: Some plants unable to instill mission and values conveyed by corporate.

pros: Good Pay, Benefits are good, most jobs are easy work, Good Training opportunities ,overtime almost always available, Lots of Paid holidays
cons: Some jobs are boring ,moat all jobs are shift work leaving no social life, we have to work most holidays. It is very hot in summer months and very cold in winter months.

pros: They offer good benefits, the pay is fair, and they have gain sharing. There is also a strong push for safety and engagement.
cons: There is too much overtime and it causes employees to leave.

review_title: Great company!  Really cares about you as a person!
pros:
They offer great benefits. Really helped me starting out. 

You get 1-to-1 meetings with your boss showing how far you've come and what path you are on. 

It isn't hard to be moved to different locations if you show you are a hard worker.
cons: It smells pretty bad in a Papermill. You get used to it, but the first week is hard.

review_title: International Paper is a very large company...Can get lost in the career maze.
pros: IP takes very good care of their employees and there is a lot of movement within the groups.
cons: 1930's style management, managers don't talk to workers.  Everyone is to worried what "level" they are.  Too many people means not much to do for may people.

pros: International Paper has great employee benefits.  I would highly recommend this employer, if you are interested in receiving great benefits.  Matching medical savings plan.
cons: Can be a very political environment.  Advancement may depend on who you know at International Paper.  Overall, a great place to work.

pros: Coworkers, for the most part, are treasures. Initial high pay is attractive.
cons: Really high health insurance premiums, and no vision insurance...both things are ridiculous for a company with 50k? employees.  This is NOT a 40 hr/wk job-- to do the extra things that will get you more opportunities you'll have to sacrifice time with family. And since there are people willing to do that, management expects it from everyone.

review_title: As often happens, my experiences varied tremendously according to which department I worked for.
pros: Benefits are great, and salaries, though very uneven, usually averaged to industry standards.  I was always able to work with my management, which wasn't always the case with previous companies.
cons: Communication skills with upper management reigns supreme, often to the detriment of having or properly using technical skills.  (This was true in my department, but certainly not in other departments.)

review_title: Great Company for Whom to Work
pros: Large company with lots of business entities and opportunities for growth.  Multiple facilities within a given geographic area allow the possibility transfer for upward growth.
cons: Due to the company size, the work environment can sometimes be a bit conservative or sterile.  Managers need to create a bit more of an individual facility feel as opposed to being part of the big conglomerate.

review_title: Lots of opportunity for results driven people. The tools and resources are there to succeed. Long term planning.
pros: I liked that the businesses are changing with the ever changing landscape. They have done a great job through the transformation year to set themselves up for the future. Good pay and opportunities. Cost of living in Memphis enables this to be a good opportunity for families.
cons: You must want to live in Memphis, TN. This is where the corporate office is.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Good company to work for. Care about their people. Very sustainable company. Competitive almost comprehensive medical plan.
cons: Education level of supervisors not as high as it should be. Hiring of associates and managers takes at least 3 months. Difficult interview process for current employees.

review_title: If you don't mind shift work, the pay is great!
pros: Great pay, no micro managing, great for self starters, little variation in the job duties, great team environment. Shift work if you're into it, allows for only working 15 days out of the month.
cons: little variation of job duties, shift work is not for every one, repetitive motion and processes of production can be dull.

job_title: Production Machine Operator in Streetsboro, OH
pros: Good pay! Friendly Employees & Management! Pretty easy work! Plenty of Overtime Availability! Management who actually takes employee safety very seriously
cons:
Overtime (if that’s not your thing) and working Saturdays during busy summer months.
Work environment is HOT in the summer.
Management turnover rate, for the most part management is very good and very helpful but can get a bad apple from time to time.

pros: Company does provide training, and management does care about professional development.
cons: Work/Life balance is not out there, supervisors are not compensated for the overtime and weekend hours.

job_title: Supply Chain Analyst in Memphis, TN
pros: The company is great at developing people.  It has a good value system and treats employees with respect.  The pay and benefits are good.  Plenty of opportunites to grow your career in a variety of roles.
cons: Moving up in the organization may require the ability to move several times in a career.  The work hours are typical business hours, however they are very flexible if you cannot be in the office for some reason.

pros: Pay was good, they gave out bonuses for good work.  Management kept employees informed with monthly meetings.  If you wanted overtime you could make a killing.
cons: Gossip, way too much talking about people behind their backs.  You'd think you were at a hair salon.  If you didn't want the overtime, you were out of luck if you didn't have seniority.  You basically worked 12 hours every day.

pros: Very forward thinking for the safety of their people. Nice pay for hourly employees.
cons: No upward movement, no training (if fact NO training what so ever for an HR). HR is an after thought at this company. Would not be a bad starting place for someone out of college, however after a couple of years start looking to move on elsewhere. Will hire outside the company before they will train you to advance.

review_title: Maintenance-Good paycheck,  lots of hours,  basic benies, Zero PTO
pros: A lot of OT, some good people,  not a really tough climate, help for tasks decent training in some areas
cons: No PTO and demerits for even sick non-pd time, clicky by shifts, forced OT with very little notice, can be targeted for blame and bad communication in dept

pros: Good people to work with and good company. Pay was fair and location was great. Good benefits as well
cons: As a process engineer you can expect the every day challenges that come with that title, need to be proactive and motivated to get the job done

pros: A lot of opportunity with the ability to readily transfer to other facilities. Great pay. Great benefits. Very strong and well established company with long term goals and a very solid plan.
cons: Very overworked and very under appreciated. Results are really the only thing that matter. Dedication and commitment do not carry the weight they should.
